SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ferdinand King of Nauarre, Berowne, Longauill, and Dumane

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferdinand.
SPEECH.LINE: Let Fame, that all hunt after in their liues, Liue registred vpon our brazen Tombes, And then grace vs in the disgrace of death: when ſpight of cormorant deuouring Time, Th’ endeuour of this present breath may buy: That honour which ſhall bate his ſythes keene edge, And make vs heyres of all eternitie. Therefore braue Conquerours, for ſo you are, That warre against your owne affections, And the huge Armie of the worlds desires. Our late edict ſhall ſtrongly ſtand in force, Nauar ſhall be the wonder of the world. Our Court ſhall be a little Achademe, Still and contemplatiue in liuing Art. You three, Berowne, Dumaine, and Longauill, Haue ſworne for three yeeres terme, to liue with me: My fellow Schollers, and to keepe those ſtatutes That are recorded in this ſcedule heere. Your oathes are past, and now ſubscribe your names: That his owne hand may ſtrike his honour downe, That violates the ſmallest branch heerein: If you are arm’d to doe, as ſworne to do, Subscribe to your deepe oathes, and keepe it to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Longauill.
SPEECH.LINE: I am resolu’d, ‘tis but a three yeeres fast:
The minde ſhall banquet, though the body pine,
Fat paunches haue leane pates: and dainty bits,
Make rich the ribs, but bankerout the wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dumane.
SPEECH.LINE: My louing Lord, Dumane is mortified,
The groſſer manner of these worlds delights,
He throwes vpon the groſſe worlds baser ſlaues:
To loue, to wealth, to pompe, I pine and die,
With all these liuing in Philosophie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berowne.
SPEECH.LINE: I can but ſay their protestation ouer,
So much, deare Liege, I haue already ſworne,
That is, to liue and ſtudy heere three yeeres.
But there are other ſtrict obseruances:
As not to ſee a woman in that terme,
Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
And one day in a weeke to touch no foode:
And but one meale on euery day beside:
The which I hope is not enrolled there.
And then to ſleepe but three houres in the night,
And not be ſeene to winke of all the day.
When I was wont to thinke no harme all night,
And make a darke night too of halfe the day:
Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
O, these are barren taskes, too hard to keepe,
Not to ſee Ladies, ſtudy, fast, not ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: Your oath is past, to paſſe away from these.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berow.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſay no my Liedge, and if you please,
I onely ſwore to ſtudy with your grace,
And ſtay heere in your Court for three yeeres ſpace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Longa.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſwore to that Berowne, and to the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berow.
SPEECH.LINE: By yea and nay ſir, than I ſwore in iest.
What is the end of ſtudy, let me know?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that to know which else wee ſhould not know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Things hid & bard (you meane) fro[m] co[m]mon ſense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: I, that is ſtudies god-like recompence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on then, I will ſweare to ſtudie ſo,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:
As thus, to ſtudy where I well may dine,
When I to fast expreſſely am forbid.
Or ſtudie where to meete ſome Mistreſſe fine,
When Mistreſſes from common ſense are hid.
Or hauing ſworne too hard a keeping oath,
Studie to breake it, and not breake my troth.
If ſtudies gaine be thus, and this be ſo,
Studie knowes that which yet it doth not know,
Sweare me to this, and I will nere ſay no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: These be the ſtops that hinder ſtudie quite,
And traine our intellects to vaine delight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? all delights are vaine, and that mo’t vaine
Which with paine purchas’d, doth inherit paine,
As painefully to poare vpon a Booke,
To ſeeke the light of truth, while truth the while
Doth falsely blinde the eye-ſight of his looke:
Light ſeeking light, doth light of light beguile:
So ere you finde where light in darkeneſſe lies,
Your light growes darke by losing of your eyes.
Studie me how to please the eye indeede,
By fixing it vpon a fairer eye,
Who dazling ſo, that eye ſhall be his heed,
And giue him light that it was blinded by.
Studie is like the heauens glorious Sunne,
That will not be deepe ſearch’d with ſawcy lookes:
Small haue continuall plodders euer wonne,
Saue base authoritie from others Bookes.
These earthly Godfathers of heauens lights,
That giue a name to euery fixed Starre,
Haue no more profit of their ſhining nights,
Then those that walke and wot not what they are.
Too much to know, is to know nought but fame:
And euery Godfather can giue a name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: How well hee's read, to reason against reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceeded well, to ſtop all good proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee weedes the corne, and ſtill lets grow the weeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: The Spring is neare when greene geeſſe are a breeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: How followes that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Fit in his place and time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: In reason nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Something then in rime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne is like an enuious ſneaping Frost,
That bites the first borne infants of the Spring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel, ſay I am, why ſhould proud Summer boast,
Before the Birds haue any cause to ſing?
Why ſhould I ioy in any abortiue birth?
At Christmas I no more desire a Rose,
Then wish a Snow in Mayes new fangled ſhowes:
But like of each thing that in ſeason growes.
So you to ſtudie now it is too late,
That were to clymbe ore the house to vnlocke the gate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſit you out: go home Berowne: adue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord, I haue ſworn to ſtay with you.
And though I haue for barbarisme ſpoke more,
Then for that Angell knowledge you can ſay,
Yet confident Ile keepe what I haue ſworne,
And bide the pennance of each three yeares day.
Giue me the paper, let me reade the ſame,
And to the ſtrictest decrees Ile write my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: How well this yeelding rescues thee from ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Item. That no woman ſhall come within a mile of my Court. Hath this bin proclaimed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Foure dayes agœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's ſee the penaltie.
On paine of loosing her tongue.
Who deuis’d this penaltie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry that did I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete Lord, and why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: To fright them hence with that dread penaltie, A dangerous law against gentilitie. Item, If any man be ſeene to talke with a woman with-in the tearme of three yeares, hee ſhall indure ſuch publique ſhame as the rest of the Court ſhall poſſibly deuise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This Article my Liedge your ſelfe must breake,
For well you know here comes in Embaſſie
The French Kings daughter, with your ſelfe to ſpeake:
A Maide of grace and compleate maiestie,
About ſurrender vp of Aquitaine:
To her decrepit, ſicke, and bed-rid Father.
Therefore this Article is made in vaine,
Or vainly comes th’ admired Princeſſe hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you Lords?
Why, this was quite forgot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: So Studie euermore is ouershot,
While it doth ſtudy to haue what it would,
It doth forget to doe the thing it ſhould:
And when it hath the thing it hunteth mo’t,
‘Tis won as townes with fire, ſo won, ſo lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: We must of force dispence with this Decree,
She must lye here on meere neceſſitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Neceſſity will make vs all forsworne
Three thousand times within this three yeeres ſpace:
For euery man with his affects is borne,
Not by might mastred, but by ſpeciall grace.
If I breake faith, this word ſhall breake for me,
I am forsworne on meere neceſſitie.
So to the Lawes at large I write my name,
And he that breakes them in the least degree,
Stands in attainder of eternall ſhame.
Suggestions are to others as to me:
But I beleeue although I ſeeme ſo loth,
I am the last that will last keepe his oth.
But is there no quicke recreation granted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I that there is, our Court you know is hanted
With a refined trauailer of Spaine,
A man in all the worlds new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his braine:
One, who the musicke of his owne vaine tongue,
Doth rauish like inchanting harmonie:
A man of complements whom right and wrong
Haue chose as vmpire of their mutinie.
This childe of fancie that Armado hight,
For interim to our ſtudies ſhall relate,
In high-borne words the worth of many a Knight:
From tawnie Spaine lost in the worlds debate.
How you delight my Lords, I know not I,
But I protest I loue to heare him lie,
And I will vse him for my Minstrelsie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Armado is a mo’t illustrious wight,
A man of fire, new words, fashions owne Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Costard the ſwaine and he, ſhall be our ſport,
And ſo to ſtudie, three yeeres is but ſhort.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter a Constable with Costard with a Letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the Dukes owne person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This fellow, What would'st?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: I my ſelfe reprehend his owne person, for I am his graces Tharborough: But I would ſee his own person in flesh and blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This is he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Con.
SPEECH.LINE: Signeor Arme, Arme commends you:
Ther's villanie abroad, this letter will tell you more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir the Contempts thereof are as touching mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How low ſœuer the matter, I hope in God for high words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: A high hope for a low heauen, God grant vs pa-tience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: To heare, or forbeare hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: To heare meekely ſir, and to laugh moderately, or to forbeare both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, be it as the ſtile ſhall giue vs cause to clime in the merrineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The matter is to me ſir, as concerning Iaquenetta.
The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: In what manner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: In manner and forme following ſir all those three. I was ſeene with her in the Mannor house, ſitting with her vpon the Forme, and taken following her into the Parke: which put to gether, is in manner and forme following. Now ſir for the manner; It is the manner of a man to ſpeake to a woman, for the forme in ſome forme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: For the following ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: As it ſhall follow in my correction, and God de-fend the right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you heare this Letter with attention?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: As we would heare an Oracle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Such is the ſimplicitie of man to harken after the flesh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferdinand.
SPEECH.LINE: Great Deputie, the Welkins Vicegerent, and ſole domi-nator of Nauar, my ſoules earths God, and bodies fo-string patrone:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a word of Costard yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: So it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be ſo: but if he ſay it is ſo, he is in telling true: but ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Be to me, and euery man that dares not fight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: No words,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Of other mens ſecrets I beseech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: So it is besieged with ſable coloured melancholie, I did commend the blacke oppreſſing humour to the mo’t whole-some Physicke of thy health-giuing ayre: And as I am a Gen-tleman, betooke my ſelfe to walke: the time When? about the ſixt houre, When beasts mo’t grase, birds best pecke, and men ſit downe to that nourishment which is called ſupper: So much for the time When. Now for the ground Which? which I meane I walkt vpon, it is ycliped, Thy Parke. Then for the place Where? where I meane I did encounter that obscene and mo’t preposterous euent that draweth from my ſnow-white pen the ebon coloured Inke, which heere thou viewest, beholdest: ſuruayest, or ſeest. But to the place Where? It ſtandeth North North-east and by East from the West corner of thy curious knotted garden; There did I ſee that low ſpiri-ted Swaine, that base Minow of thy myrth, (

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown.
SPEECH.LINE: Mee?) that vnletered ſmall knowing ſoule, (

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow
SPEECH.LINE: Me?) that ſhallow vaſſall (

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Still mee?) which as I remember, hight Co-stard,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O me) ſorted and consorted contrary to thy e-stablished proclaymed Edict and Continent, Cannon: Which with, ô with, but with this I paſſion to ſay wherewith:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: With a Wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: With a childe of our Grandmother Eue, a female; or for thy more ſweet understanding a woman: him, I (as my euer esteemed dutie prickes me on) haue ſent to thee, to receiue the meed of punishment by the ſweet Graces Officer Anthony Dull, a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, & estimation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Me, an't ſhall please you? I am Anthony Dull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferd.
SPEECH.LINE: For Iaquenetta (so is the weaker veſſell called) which I apprehended with the aforesaid Swaine, I keepe her as a veſſell of thy Lawes furie, and ſhall at the least of thy ſweet notice, bring her to triall. Thine in all complements of deuoted and heart-burning heat of dutie. Don Adriana de Armado.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not ſo well as I looked for, but the best that euer I heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I the best, for the worst. But ſirra, What ſay you to this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I confeſſe the Wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you heare the Proclamation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe confeſſe much of the hearing it, but little of the marking of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: It was proclaimed a yeeres imprisonment to bee taken with a Wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: I was taken with none ſir, I was taken with a
Damosell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, it was proclaimed Damosell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: This was no Damosell neyther ſir, ſhee was a
Virgin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo varried to, for it was proclaimed Virgin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If it were, I denie her Virginitie: I was taken with a Maide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: This Maid will not ſerue your turne ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: This Maide will ſerue my turne ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I will pronounce your ſentence: You ſhall fast a Weeke with Branne and water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I had rather pray a Moneth with Mutton and
Porridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: And Don Armado ſhall be your keeper.
My Lord Berowne, ſee him deliuer’d ore,
And goe we Lords to put in practice that,
Which each to other hath ſo ſtrongly ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile lay my head to any good mans hat,
These oathes and lawes will proue an idle ſcorne.
Sirra, come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſuffer for the truth ſir: for true it is, I was ta-ken with Iaquenetta, and Iaquenetta is a true girle, and therefore welcome the ſowre cup of prosperitie, afflicti-on may one day ſmile againe, and vntill then ſit downe ſorrow. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Armado and Moth his Page.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arma.
SPEECH.LINE: Boy, What ſigne is it when a man of great ſpirit growes melancholy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A great ſigne ſir, that he will looke ſad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? ſadneſſe is one and the ſelfe-ſame thing deare impe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: No no, O Lord ſir no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: How canst thou part ſadneſſe and melancholy my tender Iuuenall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: By a familiar demonstration of the working, my tough ſigneur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Why tough ſigneur? Why tough ſigneur?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Why tender Iuuenall? Why tender Iuuenall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpoke it tender Iuuenall, as a congruent apa-thaton, appertaining to thy young daies, which we may nominate tender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And I tough ſigneur, as an appertinent title to your olde time, which we may name tough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Pretty and apt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: How meane you ſir, I pretty, and my ſaying apt? or I apt, and my ſaying prettie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou pretty because little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Little pretty, because little: wherefore apt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: And therefore apt, because quicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake you this in my praise Master?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: In thy condigne praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I will praise an Eele with the ſame praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: What? that an Eele is ingenuous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: That an Eele is quicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe ſay thou art quicke in answeres. Thou heat'st my bloud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I am anſwer’d ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue not to be crost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſpeakes the meere contrary, croſſes loue not him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Br.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue promis’d to ſtudy iij. yeres with the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: You may doe it in an houre ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Impoſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: How many is one thrice told?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ill at reckning, it fits the ſpirit of a Tapster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a gentleman and a gamester ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I confeſſe both, they are both the varnish of a compleat man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I am ſure you know how much the groſſe ſumme of deus-ace amounts to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: It doth amount to one more then two.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Which the base vulgar call three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Br.
SPEECH.LINE: True.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir is this ſuch a peece of ſtudy? Now here's three ſtudied, ere you'll thrice wink, & how easie it is to put yeres to the word three, and ſtudy three yeeres in two words, the dancing horse will tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t fine Figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: To proue you a Cypher.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I will heereupon confeſſe I am in loue: and as it is base for a Souldier to loue; ſo am I in loue with a base wench. If drawing my ſword against the humour of affection, would deliuer mee from the reprobate thought of it, I would take Desire prisoner, and ransome him to any French Courtier for a new deuis’d curtsie. I thinke ſcorne to ſigh, me thinkes I ſhould out-sweare Cupid. Comfort me Boy, What great men haue beene in loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Hercules Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſweete Hercules: more authority deare Boy, name more; and ſweet my childe let them be men of good repute and carriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Sampson Master, he was a man of good carriage, great carriage: for hee carried the Towne-gates on his backe like a Porter: and he was in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: O well-knit Sampson, ſtrong ioynted Sampson; I doe excell thee in my rapier, as much as thou didst mee in carrying gates. I am in loue too. Who was Sampsons loue my deare Moth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A Woman, Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Of what complexion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the foure, or the three, or the two, or one of the foure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell me precisely of what complexion?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Of the ſea-water Greene ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Is that one of the foure complexions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: As I haue read ſir, and the best of them too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Greene indeed is the colour of Louers: but to haue a Loue of that colour, methinkes Sampson had ſmall reason for it. He ſurely affected her for her wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: It was ſo ſir, for ſhe had a greene wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: My Loue is mo’t immaculate white and red.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t immaculate thoughts Master, are mask’d vnder ſuch colours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Define, define, well educated infant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: My fathers witte, and my mothers tongue aſſist mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet inuocation of a childe, mo’t pretty and patheticall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſhee be made of white and red, Her faults will nere be knowne: For blush-in cheekes by faults are bred, And feares by pale white ſhowne: Then if ſhe feare, or be to blame, By this you ſhall not know, For ſtill her cheekes poſſeſſe the ſame, Which natiue ſhe doth owe: A dangerous rime master against the reason of white and redde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there not a ballet Boy, of the King and the
Begger?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: The world was very guilty of ſuch a Ballet ſome three ages ſince, but I thinke now ‘tis not to be found: or if it were, it would neither ſerue for the writing, nor the tune.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I will haue that ſubiect newly writ ore, that I may example my digreſſion by ſome mighty president. Boy, I doe loue that Countrey girle that I tooke in the Parke with the rationall hinde Costard: ſhe deserues well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: To bee whip’d: and yet a better loue then my
Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sing Boy, my ſpirit grows heauy in loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And that’s great maruell, louing a light wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay ſing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Forbeare till this company be past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Const.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the Dukes pleasure, is that you keepe Co-stard ſafe, and you must let him take no delight, nor no penance, but hee must fast three daies a weeke: for this Damsell, I must keepe her at the Parke, ſhee is alowd for the Day-woman. Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I do betray my ſelfe with blushing: Maide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maid.
SPEECH.LINE: Man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil visit thee at the Lodge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maid.
SPEECH.LINE: That's here by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I know where it is ſituate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mai.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord how wise you are!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell thee wonders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: With what face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mai.
SPEECH.LINE: So I heard you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mai.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire weather after you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo
SPEECH.LINE: Come Iaquenetta, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Villaine, thou ſhalt fast for thy offences ere thou be pardoned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, I hope when I doe it, I ſhall doe it on a full ſtomacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be heauily punished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am more bound to you then your fellowes, for they are but lightly rewarded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Take away this villaine, ſhut him vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Come you transgreſſing ſlaue, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Let mee not bee pent vp ſir, I will fast being loose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, that were fast and loose: thou ſhalt to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, if euer I do ſee the merry dayes of deso-lation that I haue ſeene, ſome ſhall ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall ſome ſee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay nothing, Master Moth, but what they looke vpon. It is not for prisoners to be ſilent in their words, and therefore I will ſay nothing: I thanke God, I haue as little patience as another man, and therefore I can be quiet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe affect the very ground (which is base) where her ſhoœ (which is baser) guided by her foote (which is basest) doth tread. I ſhall be forsworn (which is a great argument of falshood) if I loue. And how can that be true loue, which is falsly attempted? Loue is a fa-miliar, Loue is a Diuell. There is no euill Angell but Loue, yet Sampson was ſo tempted, and he had an excel-lent ſtrength: Yet was Salomon ſo ſeduced, and hee had a very good witte. Cupids Butshaft is too hard for Her-cules Clubbe, and therefore too much ods for a Spa-niards Rapier: The first and ſecond cause will not ſerue my turne: the Paſſado hee respects not, the Duello he regards not; his disgrace is to be called Boy, but his glorie is to ſubdue men. Adue Valour, rust Rapier, bee ſtill Drum, for your manager is in loue; yea hee loueth. Aſſist me ſome extemporall god of Rime, for I am ſure I ſhall turne Sonnet. Deuise Wit, write Pen, for I am for whole volumes in folio. Exit. Finis Actus Primus.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Princeſſe of France, with three attending Ladies, and three Lords

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Madam ſummon vp your dearest ſpirits,
Consider who the King your father ſends:
To whom he ſends, and what’s his Embaſſie.
Your ſelfe, held precious in the worlds esteeme,
To parlee with the ſole inheritour
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchleſſe Nauarre, the plea of no leſſe weight
Then Aquitaine, a Dowrie for a Queene,
Be now as prodigall of all deare grace,
As Nature was in making Graces deare,
When ſhe did ſtarue the generall world beside,
And prodigally gaue them all to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: Good L[ord]. Boyet, my beauty though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise:
Beauty is bought by iudgement of the eye,
Not vttred by base ſale of chapmens tongues:
I am leſſe proud to heare you tell my worth,
Then you much willing to be counted wise,
In ſpending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to taske the tasker, good Boyet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You are not ignorant all-telling fame
Doth noyse abroad Nauar hath made a vow,
Till painefull ſtudie ſhall out-weare three yeares,
No woman may approach his ſilent Court:
Therefore to's ſeemeth it a needfull course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure, and in that behalfe
Bold of your worthineſſe, we ſingle you,
As our best mouing faire ſoliciter:
Tell him, the daughter of the King of France,
On ſerious busineſſe crauing quicke dispatch,
Importunes personall conference with his grace.
Haste, ſignifie ſo much while we attend,
Like humble visag’d ſuters his high will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: Proud of imployment, willingly I goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: All pride is willing pride, and yours is ſo: Who are the Votaries my Louing Lords, that are vow-fellowes with this vertuous Duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Longauill is one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Princ.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you the man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1 Lady.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him Madame at a marriage feast,
Betweene L[ord]. Perigort and the beautious heire
Of Iaques Fauconbridge ſolemnized.
In Normandie ſaw I this Longauill,
A man of ſoueraigne parts he is esteem’d:
Well fitted in Arts, glorious in Armes:
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The onely ſoyle of his faire vertues gloſſe,
If vertues gloſſe will ſtaine with any ſoile,
Is a ſharp wit match’d with too blunt a Will:
Whose edge hath power to cut whose will ſtill wills,
It ſhould none ſpare that come within his power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Some merry mocking Lord belike, ist ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.1.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay ſo mo’t, that mo’t his humors know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: such ſhort liu’d wits do wither as they grow. Who are the rest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Lad.
SPEECH.LINE: The yong Dumaine, a well accomplisht youth,
Of all that Vertue loue, for Vertue loued.
Mo’t power to doe mo’t harme, least knowing ill:
For he hath wit to make an ill ſhape good,
And ſhape to win grace though ſhe had no wit.
I ſaw him at the Duke Alansœs once,
And much too little of that good I ſaw,
Is my report to his great worthineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Another of these Students at that time,
Was there with him, as I haue heard a truth.
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becomming mirth,
I neuer ſpent an houres talke withall.
His eye begets occasion for his wit,
For euery obiect that the one doth catch,
The other turnes to a mirth-mouing iest.
Which his faire tongue (conceits expositor)
Deliuers in ſuch apt and gracious words,
That aged eares play treuant at his tales,
And yonger hearings are quite rauished.
So ſweet and voluble is his discourse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe my Ladies, are they all in loue?
That euery one her owne hath garnished,
With ſuch bedecking ornaments of praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes Boyet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, what admittance Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Nauar had notice of your faire approach;
And he and his competitors in oath,
Were all addrest to meete you gentle Lady
Before I came: Marrie thus much I haue learnt,
He rather meanes to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes heere to besiege his Court,
Then ſeeke a dispensation for his oath:
To let you enter his vnpeopled house.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Enter Nauar, Longauill, Dumaine, and Berowne.

SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes Nauar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Princeſſe, welcom to the Court of Nauar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire I giue you backe againe, and welcome I haue not yet: the roofe of this Court is too high to bee yours, and welcome to the wide fields, too base to be mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall be welcome Madam to my Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil be welcome then, Conduct me thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me deare Lady, I haue ſworne an oath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Lady helpe my Lord, he'll be forsworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: Not for the world faire Madam, by my will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, will ſhall breake it will, and nothing els.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Ladiship is ignorant what it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Were my Lord ſo, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must proue ignorance.
I heare your grace hath ſworne out House-keeping:
‘Tis deadly ſinne to keepe that oath my Lord,
And ſinne to breake it:
But pardon me, I am too ſodaine bold,
To teach a Teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my comming,
And ſodainly resolue me in my ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nau.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I will, if ſodainly I may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You will the ſooner that I were away,
For you'll proue periur’d if you make me ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berow.
SPEECH.LINE: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: How needleſſe was it then to ask the question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You must not be ſo quicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis long of you y ſpur me with ſuch questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Your wit's too hot, it ſpeeds too fast, 'twill tire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till it leaue the Rider in the mire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What time a day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: The howre that fooles ſhould aske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Now faire befall your maske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire fall the face it couers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſend you many louers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, ſo you be none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then will I be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, your father heere doth intimate,
The paiment of a hundred thousand Crownes,
Being but th’ one halfe, of an intire ſumme,
Disbursed by my father in his warres.
But ſay that he, or we, as neither haue
Receiu’d that ſumme; yet there remaines vnpaid
A hundred thousand more: in ſurety of the which,
One part of Aquitaine is bound to vs,
Although not valued to the moneys worth.
If then the King your father will restore
But that one halfe which is vnsatisfied,
We will giue vp our right in Aquitaine,
And hold faire friendship with his Maiestie:
But that it ſeemes he little purposeth,
For here he doth demand to haue repaie,
An hundred thousand Crownes, and not demands
One paiment of a hundred thousand Crownes,
To haue his title liue in Aquitaine.
Which we much rather had depart withall,
And haue the money by our father lent,
Then Aquitane, ſo guelded as it is.
Deare Princeſſe, were not his requests ſo farre
From reasons yeelding, your faire ſelfe ſhould make
A yeelding 'gainst ſome reason in my brest,
And goe well ſatisfied to France againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe the King my Father too much wrong,
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In ſo vnseeming to confeſſe receyt
Of that which hath ſo faithfully beene paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe protest I neuer heard of it,
And if you proue it, Ile repay it backe,
Or yeeld vp Aquitaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: We arrest your word:
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For ſuch a ſumme, from ſpeciall Officers,
Of Charles his Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Satisfie me ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other ſpecialties are bound,
To morrow you ſhall haue a ſight of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall ſuffice me; at which enterview,
All liberall reason would I yeeld vnto:
Meane time, receiue ſuch welcome at my hand,
As honour, without breach of Honour may
Make tender of, to thy true worthineſſe.
You may not come faire Princeſſe in my gates,
But heere without you ſhall be ſo receiu’d,
As you ſhall deeme your ſelfe lodg’d in my heart,
Though ſo deni’d farther harbour in my house:
Your owne good thoughts excuse me, and farewell,
To morrow we ſhall visit you againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet health & faire desires consort your grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin
SPEECH.LINE: Thy own wish wish I thee, in euery place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Lady, I will commend you to my owne heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you doe my commendations,
I would be glad to ſee it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you heard it grone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Is the ſoule ſicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Sicke at the heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, let it bloud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Would that doe it good?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: My Phisicke ſaies I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you prick't with your eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: No poynt, with my knife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Now God ſaue thy life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: And yours from long liuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot ſtay thanks-giuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I pray you a word: What Lady is that ſame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: The heire of Alanson, Rosalin her name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: A gallant Lady, Mounsier fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you a word: what is ſhe in the white?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A woman ſomtimes, if you ſaw her in the light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Perchance light in the light: I desire her name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee hath but one for her ſelfe,
To desire that were a ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſir, whose daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Her Mothers, I haue heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Gods bleſſing a your beard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſir be not offended,
Shee is an heyre of Faulconbridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, my choller is ended:
Shee is a mo’t ſweet Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Not vnlike ſir, that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What's her name in the cap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Katherine by good hap.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe wedded, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: To her will ſir, or ſo,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You are welcome ſir, adiew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: Fare well to me ſir, and welcome to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: That last is Beroune, the mery mad-cap Lord.
Not a word with him, but a iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And euery iest but a word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pri.
SPEECH.LINE: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I was as willing to grapple, as he was to boord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: Two hot Sheepes marie:
And wherefore not Ships?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sheepe (sweet Lamb) vnleſſe we feed on your lips.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: You Sheepe & I pasture: ſhall that finish the iest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: So you grant pasture for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo gentle beast.
My lips are no Common, though ſeuerall they be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bo.
SPEECH.LINE: Belonging to whom?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: To my fortunes and me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good wits wil be iangling, but gentles agree.
This ciuill warre of wits were much better vsed
On Nauar and his bookemen, for heere ‘tis abus’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bo.
SPEECH.LINE: If my obseruation (which very ſeldome lies
By the hearts ſtill rhetoricke, disclosed with eyes)
Deceiue me not now, Nauar is infected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: With what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bo.
SPEECH.LINE: With that which we Louers intitle affected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Your reason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why all his behauiours doe make their retire,
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire.
His hart like an Agot with your print impreſſed,
Proud with his forme, in his eie pride expreſſed.
His tongue all impatient to ſpeake and not ſee,
Did ſtumble with haste in his eie-ſight to be,
All ſences to that ſence did make their repaire,
To feele onely looking on fairest of faire:
Me thought all his ſences were lockt in his eye,
As Iewels in Christall for ſome Prince to Buy.
Who tendring their own worth from whence they were glast,
Did point out to buy them along as you past.
His faces owne margent did coate ſuch amazes,
That all eyes ſaw his eies inchanted with gazes.
Ile giue you Aquitaine, and all that is his,
And you giue him for my ſake, but one louing Kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come to our Pauillion, Boyet is disposde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bro.
SPEECH.LINE: But to ſpeak that in words, which his eie hath disclos’d.
I onelie haue made a mouth of his eie,
By adding a tongue, which I know will not lie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art an old Loue-monger, and ſpeakest ſkilfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: He is Cupids Grandfather, and learnes news of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.2.
SPEECH.LINE: Then was Venus like her mother, for her fa-ther is but grim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you heare my mad wenches?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.1.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: What then, do you ſee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lad.2.
SPEECH.LINE: I, our way to be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: You are too hard for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: Warble childe, make paſſionate my ſense of hea-ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Concolinel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete Ayer, go tenderneſſe of yeares: take this Key, giue enlargement to the ſwaine, bring him fe-stinatly hither: I must imploy him in a letter to my Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you win your loue with a French braule?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: How meanest thou, brauling in French?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: No my compleat master, but to Iigge off a tune at the tongues end, canarie to it with the feete, humour it with turning vp your eie: ſigh a note and ſing a note, ſometime through the throate: if you ſwallowed loue with ſinging, loue ſometime through: nose as if you ſnuft vp loue by ſmelling loue with your hat penthouse-like ore the ſhop of your eies, with your armes crost on your thinbellie doublet, like a Rabbet on a ſpit, or your hands in your pocket, like a man after the old painting, and keepe not too long in one tune, but a ſnip and away: these are complements, these are humours, these betraie nice wenches that would be betraied without these, and make them men of note: do you note men that mo’t are affected to these?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: How hast thou purchased this experience?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: By my penne of obseruation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: But O, but O.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: The Hobbie-horse is forgot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: Cal'st thou my loue Hobbi-horse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: No Master, the Hobbie-horse is but a Colt, and and your Loue perhaps, a Hacknie: but haue you forgot your Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Almost I had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Negligent ſtudent, learne her by heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: By heart, and in heart Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And out of heart Master: all those three I will proue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou proue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A man, if I liue (and this) by, in, and without, vp-on the instant: by heart you loue her, because your heart cannot come by her: in heart you loue her, because your heart is in loue with her: and out of heart you loue her, being out of heart that you cannot enioy her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I am all these three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And three times as much more, and yet nothing at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Fetch hither the Swaine, he must carrie mee a letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A meſſage well ſimpathis’d, a Horse to be em-baſſadour for an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, What ſaiest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir, you must ſend the Aſſe vpon the Horse for he is verie ſlow gated: but I goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The way is but ſhort, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: As ſwift as Lead ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy meaning prettie ingenious, is not Lead a mettall heauie, dull, and ſlow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Minnime honeſt Master, or rather Master no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay Lead is ſlow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too ſwift ſir to ſay ſo.
Is that Lead ſlow which is fir’d from a Gunne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweete ſmoke of Rhetorike,
He reputes me a Cannon, and the Bullet that’s he:
I ſhoote thee at the Swaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Thump then, and I flee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t acute Iuuenall, voluble and free of grace,
By thy fauour ſweet Welkin, I must ſigh in thy face.
Mo’t rude melancholie, Valour giues thee place.
My Herald is return’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: A wonder Master, here's a Costard broken in a ſhin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Some enigma, ſome riddle, come, thy Lenuoy begin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No egma, no riddle, no lenuoy, no ſalue, in thee male ſir. Or ſir, Plantan, a plaine Plantan: no lenuoy, no lenuoy, no Salue ſir, but a Plantan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: By vertue, thou inforcest laughter, thy ſillie thought, my ſpleene, the heauing of my lunges prouokes me to rediculous ſmyling: O pardon me my ſtars, doth the inconsiderate take ſalue for lenuoy, and the word len-uoy for a ſalue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe the wise thinke them other, is not lenuoy a ſalue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: No Page, it is an epilogue or discourse to make plaine, Some obscure precedence that hath tofore bin faine. Now will I begin your morrall, and do you follow with my lenuoy. The Foxe, the Ape, and the Humble-Bee, Were ſtill at oddes, being but three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arm.
SPEECH.LINE: Vntill the Goose came out of doore,
Staying the oddes by adding foure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: A good Lenuoy, ending in the Goose: would you desire more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The Boy hath ſold him a bargaine, a Goose, that’s flat.
Sir, your penny-worth is good, and your Goose be fat.
To ſell a bargaine well is as cunning as fast and loose:
Let me ſee a fat Lenuoy, I that’s a fat Goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither, come hither:
How did this argument begin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: By ſaying that a Costard was broken in a ſhin.
Then cal’d you for the Lenuoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and I for a Plantan:
Thus came your argument in:
Then the Boyes fat Lenuoy, the Goose that you bought,
And he ended the market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: But tell me: How was there a Costard broken in a ſhin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you ſencibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast no feeling of it Moth,
I will ſpeake that Lenuoy.
I Costard running out, that was ſafely within,
Fell ouer the threshold, and broke my ſhin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arm.
SPEECH.LINE: We will talke no more of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Till there be more matter in the ſhin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arm.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirra Costard, I will infranchise thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O, marrie me to one Francis, I ſmell ſome Len-uoy, ſome Goose in this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arm.
SPEECH.LINE: By my ſweete ſoule, I meane, ſetting thee at li-bertie. Enfreedoming thy person: thou wert emured, restrained, captiuated, bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: True, true, and now you will be my purgation, and let me loose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Arm.
SPEECH.LINE: I giue thee thy libertie, ſet thee from durance, and in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but this: Beare this ſignificant to the countrey Maide Iaquenetta: there is remuneration, for the best ward of mine honours is rewarding my dependants. Moth, follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Like the ſequell I.
Signeur Costard adew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: My ſweete ounce of mans flesh, my in-conie Iew: Now will I looke to his remuneration. Remuneration, O, that’s the Latine word for three-far-things: Three-farthings remuneration, What's the price of this yncle? i.d. no, Ile giue you a remuneration: Why? It carries it remuneration: Why? It is a fairer name then a French-Crowne. I will neuer buy and ſell out of this word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O my good knaue Costard, exceedingly well met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you ſir, How much Carnation Ribbon may a man buy for a remuneration?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What is a remuneration?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie ſir, halfe pennie farthing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O, Why then threefarthings worth of Silke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your worship, God be wy you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſtay ſlaue, I must employ thee:
As thou wilt win my fauour, good my knaue,
Doe one thing for me that I ſhall intreate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: When would you haue it done ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O this after-noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I will doe it ſir: Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou knowest not what it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall know ſir, when I haue done it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why villaine thou must know first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil come to your worship to morrow morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: It must be done this after-noone,
Harke ſlaue, it is but this:
The Princeſſe comes to hunt here in the Parke,
And in her traine there is a gentle Ladie:
When tongues ſpeak ſweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her, aske for her:
And to her white hand ſee thou do commend
This ſeal’d-vp counsaile. Ther's thy guerdon: goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Gardon, O ſweete gardon, better then remune-ration, a leuenpence-farthing better: mo’t ſweete gar-don. I will doe it ſir in print: gardon, remuneration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O, and I forsooth in loue,
I that haue beene loues whip?
A verie Beadle to a humerous ſigh: A Criticke,
Nay, a night-watch Constable.
A domineering pedant ore the Boy,
Then whom no mortall ſo magnificent,
This wimpled, whyning, purblinde waiward Boy,
This ſignior Iunios gyant dwarfe, don Cupid,
Regent of Loue-rimes, Lord of folded armes,
Th’ annointed ſoueraigne of ſighes and groanes:
Liedge of all loyterers and malecontents:
Dread Prince of Placcats, King of Codpeeces.
Sole Emperator and great generall
Of trotting Parrators (O my little heart.)
And I to be a Corporall of his field,
And weare his colours like a Tumblers hoope.
What? I loue, I ſue, I ſeeke a wife,
A woman that is like a Germane Cloake,
Still a repairing: euer out of frame,
And neuer going a right, being a Watch:
But being watcht, that it may ſtill goe right.
Nay, to be periurde, which is worst of all:
And among three, to loue the worst of all,
A whitly wanton, with a veluet brow.
With two pitch bals ſtucke in her face for eyes.
I, and by heauen, one that will doe the deede,
Though Argus were her Eunuch and her garde.
And I to ſigh for her, to watch for her,
To pray for her, go to: it is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect,
Of his almighty dreadfull little might.
Well, I will loue, write, ſigh, pray, ſhue, grone,
Some men must loue my Lady, and ſome Ione.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Princeſſe, a Forrester, her Ladies, and her Lords

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Was that the King that ſpurd his horse ſo hard,
Against the ſteepe vprising of the hill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not, but I thinke it was not he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ere a was, a ſhew’d a mounting minde:
Well Lords, to day we ſhall haue our dispatch,
On Saterday we will returne to France.
Then Forrester my friend, Where is the Bush
That we must ſtand and play the murtherer in?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Hereby vpon the edge of yonder Coppice,
A ſtand where you may make the fairest ſhoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke my beautie, I am faire that ſhoote,
And thereupon thou ſpeak'st the fairest ſhoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me Madam, for I meant not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What, what? First praise me, & then again ſay no.
O ſhort liu’d pride. Not faire? alacke for wœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Madam faire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, neuer paint me now,
Where faire is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here (good my glaſſe) take this for telling true:
Faire paiment for foule words, is more then due.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but faire is that which you inherit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: See, ſee, my beautie will be ſau’d by merit.
O heresie in faire, fit for these dayes,
A giuing hand, though foule, ſhall haue faire praise.
But come, the Bow: Now Mercie goes to kill,
And ſhooting well, is then accounted ill:
Thus will I ſaue my credit in the ſhoote,
Not wounding, pittie would not let me do't:
If wounding, then it was to ſhew my ſkill,
That more for praise, then purpose meant to kill.
And out of question, ſo it is ſometimes:
Glory growes guiltie of detested crimes,
When for Fames ſake, for praise an outward part,
We bend to that, the working of the hart.
As I for praise alone now ſeeke to ſpill
The poore Deeres blood, that my heart meanes no ill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not curst wiues hold that ſelfe-soueraigntie
Onely for praise ſake, when they ſtriue to be
Lords ore their Lords?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Onely for praise, and praise we may afford,
To any Lady that ſubdewes a Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes a member of the common-wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: God dig-you-den all, pray you which is the head
Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt know her fellow, by the rest that haue no heads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the greatest Lady, the highest?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The thickest, and the tallest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: The thickest, & the tallest: it is ſo, truth is truth.
And your waste Mistris, were as ſlender as my wit,
One a these Maides girdles for your waste ſhould be fit.
Are not you the chiefe woma[n]? You are the thickest here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your will ſir? What's your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a Letter from Monsier Berowne,
To one Lady Rosaline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: O thy letter, thy letter: He's a good friend of mine.
Stand a ſide good bearer.
Boyet, you can carue,
Breake vp this Capon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: I am bound to ſerue.
This Letter is mistooke: it importeth none here:
It is writ to Iaquenetta.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: We will read it, I ſweare. Breake the necke of the Waxe, and euery one giue eare. Boyet reades. By heauen, that thou art faire, is mo’t infallible: true that thou art beauteous, truth it ſelfe that thou art louely: more fairer then faire, beautifull then beautious, truer then truth it ſelfe: haue comiseration on thy heroi-call Vaſſall. The magnanimous and mo’t illustrate King Cophetua ſet eie vpon the pernicious and indubitate Beg-ger Zenelophon: and he it was that might rightly ſay, Ve-ni, vidi, vici: Which to annothanize in the vulgar, O base and obscure vulgar; videliset, He came, See, and o-uercame: hee came one; ſee, two; ouercame three: Who came? the King. Why did he come? to ſee. Why did he ſee? to ouercome. To whom came he? to the Begger. What ſaw he? the Begger. Who ouercame he? the Begger. The conclusion is victorie: On whose ſide? the King: the captiue is inricht: On whose ſide? the Beggers. The catastrophe is a Nuptiall: on whose ſide? the Kings: no, on both in one, or one in both. I am the King (for ſo ſtands the comparison) thou the Beg-ger, for ſo witneſſeth thy lowlineſſe. Shall I command thy loue? I may. Shall I enforce thy loue? I could. Shall I entreate thy loue? I will. What, ſhalt thou ex-change for ragges, roabes: for tittles titles, for thy ſelfe mee. Thus expecting thy reply, I prophane my lips on thy foote, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy euerie part. Thine in the dearest designe of industrie, Don Adriana de Armatho. Thus dost thou heare the Nemean Lion roare, Gainst thee thou Lambe, that ſtandest as his pray: Submiſſiue fall his princely feete before, And he from forrage will incline to play. But if thou ſtriue (poore ſoule) what art thou then? Foode for his rage, repasture for his den.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What plume of feathers is hee that indited this Letter? What veine? What Wethercocke? Did you euer heare better?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I am much deceiued, but I remember the ſtile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Else your memorie is bad, going ore it erewhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court
A Phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes ſport
To the Prince and his Booke-mates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou fellow, a word.
Who gaue thee this Letter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: I told you, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: To whom ſhould'st thou giue it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: From my Lord to my Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: From which Lord, to which Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine,
To a Lady of France, that he call’d Rosaline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come Lords away.
Here ſweete, put vp this, 'twill be thine another day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is the ſhooter? Who is the ſhooter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I teach you to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I my continent of beautie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhe that beares the Bow. Finely put off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lady goes to kill hornes, but if thou marrie,
Hang me by the necke, if hornes that yeare miscarrie.
Finely put on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Well then, I am the ſhooter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And who is your Deare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: If we choose by the hornes, your ſelfe come not neare. Finely put on indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maria.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſtill wrangle with her Boyet, and ſhee ſtrikes at the brow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhe her ſelfe is hit lower:
Haue I hit her now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I come vpon thee with an old ſaying, that was a man when King Pippin of France was a little boy, as touching the hit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: So I may answere thee with one as old that was a woman when Queene Guinouer of Brittaine was a little wench, as touching the hit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it my good man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot, cannot, cannot:
And I cannot, another can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth mo’t pleasant, how both did fit it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: A marke marueilous well ſhot, for they both did hit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A mark, O marke but that marke: a marke ſaies my Lady. Let the mark haue a pricke in't, to meat at, if it may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Wide a'th bow hand, yfaith your hand is out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede a' must ſhoote nearer, or heele ne're hit the clout.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: And if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Then will ſhee get the vpshoot by cleauing the is in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ma.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you talke greasely, your lips grow foule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: She's too hard for you at pricks, ſir challenge her to boule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare too much rubbing: good night my good
Oule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By my ſoule a Swaine, a mo’t ſimple Clowne. Lord, Lord, how the Ladies and I haue put him downe. O my troth mo’t ſweete iests, mo’t inconie vulgar wit, When it comes ſo ſmoothly off, ſo obscenely, as it were, ſo fit. Armathor ath to the ſide, O a mo’t dainty man. To ſee him walke before a Lady, and to beare her Fan. To ſee him kiſſe his hand, and how mo’t ſweetly a will ſweare: And his Page atother ſide, that handfull of wit, Ah heauens, it is mo’t patheticall nit. Sowla, ſowla. Exeunt. Shoote within

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Dull, Holofernes, the Pedant and Nathaniel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nat.
SPEECH.LINE: Very reuerent ſport truely, and done in the testi-mony of a good conscience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: The Deare was (as you know) ſanguis in blood, ripe as a Pomwater who now hangeth like a Iewell in the eare of Celo the ſkie; the welken the heauen, and a-non falleth like a Crab on the face of Terra, the ſoyle, the land, the earth. Curat.Nath. Truely M[aster]. Holofernes, the epythithes are ſweetly varied like a ſcholler at the least: but ſir I aſſure ye, it was a Bucke of the first head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas not a haud credo, 'twas a Pricket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t barbarous intimation: yet a kinde of insi-nuation, as it were in via, in way of explication facere: as it were replication, or rather ostentare, to ſhow as it were his inclination after his vndreſſed, vnpolished, vneduca-ted, vnpruned, vntrained, or rather vnlettered, or rathe-rest vnconfirmed fashion, to insert againe my haud credo for a Deare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaid the Deare was not a haud credo, 'twas a
Pricket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Twice ſod ſimplicitie, bis coctus, O thou mon-ster
Ignorance, how deformed doost thou looke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir hee hath neuer fed of the dainties that are bred in a booke. He hath not eate paper as it were: He hath not drunke inke. His intellect is not replenished, hee is onely an animall, onely ſensible in the duller parts: and ſuch barren plants are ſet before vs, that we thankfull ſhould be: which we taste and feeling, are for those parts that doe fructifie in vs more then he. For as it would ill become me to be vaine, indiscreet, or a foole; So were there a patch ſet on Learning, to ſee him in a Schoole. But omne bene ſay I, being of an old Fathers minde, Many can brooke the weather, that loue not the winde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: You two are book-men: Can you tell by your wit, What was a month old at Cains birth, that’s not fiue weekes old as yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Dictisima goodman Dull, dictisima goodman
Dull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: What is dictima?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: A title to Phebe, to Luna, to the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: The Moone was a month old when Adam was no more. And wrought not to fiue-weekes when he came to fiuescore. Th’ allusion holds in the Exchange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true indeede, the Collusion holds in the
Exchange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: God comfort thy capacity, I ſay th’ allusion holds in the Exchange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: And I ſay the polusion holds in the Exchange: for the Moone is neuer but a month old: and I ſay be-side that, 'twas a Pricket that the Princeſſe kill’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Nathaniel, will you heare an extemporall Epytaph on the death of the Deare, and to humour the ignorant call’d the Deare, the Princeſſe kill’d a Pricket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Perge, good M[aster]. Holofernes, perge, ſo it ſhall please you to abrogate ſcurilitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſomething affect a letter, for it argues facilitie. The prayfull Princeſſe pearst and prickt a prettie pleasing Pricket, Some ſay a Sore, but not a ſore, till now made ſore with ſhooting. The Dogges did yell, put ell to Sore, then Sorrell iumps from thicket: Or Pricket-sore, or else Sorell, the people fall a hooting. If Sore be ſore, than ell to Sore, makes fiftie ſores O ſorell: Of one ſore I an hundred make by adding but one more L.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: A rare talent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dul.
SPEECH.LINE: If a talent be a claw, looke how he clawes him with a talent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a gift that I haue ſimple: ſimple, a foo-lish extrauagant ſpirit, full of formes, figures, ſhapes, ob-iects, Ideas, apprehensions, motions, reuolutions. These are begot in the ventricle of memorie, nourisht in the wombe of primater, and deliuered vpon the mellowing of occasion: but the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I am thankfull for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and ſo may my parishioners, for their Sonnes are well tutor’d by you, and their Daughters profit very greatly vnder you: you are a good member of the common-wealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Me hercle, If their Sonnes be ingenuous, they ſhall want no instruction: If their Daughters be capable, I will put it to them. But Vir ſapis qui pauca loquitur, a ſoule Feminine ſaluteth vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaqu.
SPEECH.LINE: God giue you good morrow M[aster]. Person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Master Person, quasi Person? And if one ſhould be perst, Which is the one?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry M[aster]. Schoolemaster, hee that is likest to a hogshead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Of persing a Hogshead, a good luster of con-ceit in a turph of Earth, Fire enough for a Flint, Pearle enough for a Swine: ‘tis prettie, it is well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaqu.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Master Parson be ſo good as reade mee this Letter, it was giuen mee by Costard, and ſent mee from Don Armatho: I beseech you read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Facile precor gellida, quando pecas omnia ſub vm-bra ruminat, and ſo forth. Ah good old Mantuan, I may ſpeake of thee as the traueiler doth of Venice, vem-chie, vencha, que non te vnde, que non te perreche. Old Man-tuan, old Mantuan. Who vnderstandeth thee not, vt re ſol la mi fa: Vnder pardon ſir, What are the contents? or rather as Horrace ſayes in his, What my ſoule verses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, and very learned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me heare a ſtaffe, a ſtanze, a verse, Lege do-mine. _ If Loue make me forsworne, how ſhall I ſweare to loue? Ah neuer faith could hold, if not to beautie vowed. Though to my ſelfe forsworn, to thee Ile faithfull proue. Those thoughts to mee were Okes, to thee like Osiers bowed. Studie his byas leaues, and makes his booke thine eyes. Where all those pleasures liue, that Art would compre-hend. _ If knowledge be the marke, to know thee ſhall ſuffice. Well learned is that tongue, that well can thee co[m]mend. All ignorant that ſoule, that ſees thee without wonder. Which is to me ſome praise, that I thy parts admire; Thy eye Ioues lightning beares, thy voyce his dreadfull thunder. Which not to anger bent, is musique, and ſweete fire. Celestiall as thou art, Oh pardon loue this wrong, That ſings heauens praise, with ſuch an earthly tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: You finde not the apostraphas, and ſo miſſe the accent. Let me ſuperuise the cangenet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Here are onely numbers ratified, but for the elegancy, facility, & golden cadence of pœsie caret: O-uiddius Naso was the man. And why in deed Naso, but for ſmelling out the odoriferous flowers of fancy? the ierkes of inuention imitarie is nothing: So doth the Hound his master, the Ape his keeper, the tyred Horse his rider: But Damosella virgin, Was this directed to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaq.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir from one mounsier Berowne, one of the ſtrange Queenes Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ouerglance the ſuperscript. To the ſnow-white hand of the mo’t beautious Lady Rosaline. I will looke againe on the intellect of the Letter, for the nomination of the partie written to the person writ-ten vnto. Your Ladiships in all desired imployment, Berowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Holofernes, this Berowne is one of the Votaries with the King, and here he hath framed a Letter to a ſe-quent of the ſtranger Queens: which accidentally, or by the way of progreſſion, hath miscarried. Trip and goe my ſweete, deliuer this Paper into the hand of the King, it may concerne much: ſtay not thy complement, I forgiue thy duetie, adue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maid.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Costard go with me:
Sir God ſaue your life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost
SPEECH.LINE: Haue with thee my girle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hol.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir you haue done this in the feare of God very religiously: and as a certaine Father ſaith

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir tell not me of the Father, I do feare coloura-ble colours. But to returne to the Verses, Did they please you ſir Nathaniel?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nath.
SPEECH.LINE: Marueilous well for the pen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I do dine to day at the fathers of a certaine Pu-pill of mine, where if (being repast) it ſhall please you to gratifie the table with a Grace, I will on my priuiledge I haue with the parents of the foresaid Childe or Pupill, vndertake your bien venuto, where I will proue those Verses to be very vnlearned, neither ſauouring of Pœtrie, Wit, nor Inuention. I beseech your So-cietie. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nat.
SPEECH.LINE: And thanke you to: for ſocietie (saith the text) is the happineſſe of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: And certes the text mo’t infallibly concludes it. Sir I do inuite you too, you ſhall not ſay me nay: pauca verba. Away, the gentles are at their game, and we will to our recreation. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Berowne with a Paper in his hand, alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: The King he is hunting the Deare, I am coursing my ſelfe. They haue pitcht a Toyle, I am toyling in a pytch, pitch that defiles; defile, a foule word: Well, ſet thee downe ſorrow; for ſo they ſay the foole ſaid, and ſo ſay I, and I the foole: Well proued wit. By the Lord this Loue is as mad as Aiax, it kils ſheepe, it kils mee, I a ſheepe: Well proued againe a my ſide. I will not loue; if I do hang me: yfaith I will not. O but her eye: by this light, but for her eye, I would not loue her; yes, for her two eyes. Well, I doe nothing in the world but lye, and lye in my throate. By heauen I doe loue, and it hath taught mee to Rime, and to be mallicholie: and here is part of my Rime, and heere my mallicholie. Well, ſhe hath one a'my Sonnets already, the Clowne bore it, the Foole ſent it, and the Lady hath it: ſweet Clowne, ſwee-ter Foole, ſweetest Lady. By the world, I would not care a pin, if the other three were in. Here comes one with a paper, God giue him grace to grone.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He ſtands aside. The King entreth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay mee!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Shot by heauen: proceede ſweet Cupid, thou hast thumpt him with thy Birdbolt vnder the left pap: in faith ſecrets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſweete a kiſſe the golden Sunne giues not,
To those fresh morning drops vpon the Rose,
As thy eye beames, when their fresh rayse haue ſmot.
The night of dew that on my cheekes downe flowes.
Nor ſhines the ſiluer Moone one halfe ſo bright,
Through the transparent bosome of the deepe,
As doth thy face through teares of mine giue light:
Thou ſhin'st in euery teare that I doe weepe,
No drop, but as a Coach doth carry thee:
So ridest thou triumphing in my wœ.
Do but behold the teares that ſwell in me,
And they thy glory through my griefe will ſhow:
But doe not loue thy ſelfe, then thou wilt keepe
My teares for glaſſes, and ſtill make me weepe.
O Queene of Queenes, how farre dost thou excell,
No thought can thinke, nor tongue of mortall tell.
How ſhall ſhe know my griefes? Ile drop the paper.
Sweete leaues ſhade folly. Who is he comes heere?

LINE.STAGEDIR: Enter Longauile. The King ſteps aside.

SPEECH.LINE: What Longauill, and reading: listen eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Now in thy likeneſſe, one more foole appeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Ay me, I am forsworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he comes in like a periure, wearing papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: In loue I hope, ſweet fellowship in ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: One drunkard loues another of the name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I the first y haue been periur’d ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I could put thee in comfort, not by two that I know,
Thou makest the triumphery, the corner cap of ſocietie,
The ſhape of Loues Tiburne, that hangs vp ſimplicitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare these ſtubborn lines lack power to moue.
O ſweet Maria, Empreſſe of my Loue,
These numbers will I teare, and write in prose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O Rimes are gards on wanton Cupids hose,
Disfigure not his Shop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon
SPEECH.LINE: This ſame ſhall goe. He reades the Sonnet.
Did not the heauenly Rhetoricke of thine eye,
'Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Perswade my heart to this false periurie?
Vowes for thee broke deserue not punishment.
A Woman I forswore, but I will proue,
Thou being a Goddeſſe, I forswore not thee.
My Vow was earthly, thou a heauenly Loue.
Thy grace being gain’d, cures all disgrace in me.
Vowes are but breath, and breath a vapour is.
Then thou faire Sun, which on my earth doest ſhine,
Exhalest this vapor-vow, in thee it is:
If broken then, it is no fault of mine:
If by me broke, What foole is not ſo wise,
To loose an oath, to win a Paradise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the liuer veine, which makes flesh a deity.
A greene Goose, a Goddeſſe, pure pure Idolatry.
God amend vs, God amend, we are much out o'th’ way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: By whom ſhall I ſend this (company?) Stay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: All hid, all hid, an old infant play,
Like a demie God, here ſit I in the ſkie,
And wretched fooles ſecrets heedfully ore-eye.
More Sacks to the myll. O heauens I haue my wish,
Dumaine transform’d, foure Woodcocks in a dish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: O mo’t diuine Kate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: O mo’t prophane coxcombe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen the wonder of a mortall eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: By earth ſhe is not, corporall, there you lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Her Amber haires for foule hath amber coted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: An Amber coloured Rauen was well noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: As vpright as the Cedar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Stoope I ſay, her ſhoulder is with-child.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: As faire as day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I as ſome daies, but then no ſunne must ſhine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: O that I had my wish?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: And I had mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: And mine too good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen, ſo I had mine: Is not that a good word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I would forget her, but a Feuer ſhe
Raignes in my bloud, and will remembred be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A Feuer in your bloud, why then incision
Would let her out in Sawcers, ſweet misprision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Once more Ile read the Ode that I haue writ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Once more Ile marke how Loue can varry Wit. Dumane reades his Sonnet. On a day, alack the day: Loue, whose Month is euery May, Spied a bloſſome paſſing faire, Playing in the wanton ayre: Through the Veluet, leaues the winde, All vnseene, can paſſage finde. That the Louer ſicke to death, Wish himselfe the heauens breath. Ayre (quoth he) thy cheekes may blowe, Ayre, would I might triumph ſo. But alacke my hand is ſworne, Nere to plucke thee from thy throne: Vow alacke for youth vnmeete, youth ſo apt to plucke a ſweet. Doe not call it ſinne in me, That I am forsworne for thee. Thou for whom Ioue would ſweare, Iuno but an Aethiop were, And denie himselfe for Ioue. Turning mortall for thy Loue. This will I ſend, and ſomething else more plaine. That ſhall expreſſe my true-loues fasting paine. O would the King, Berowne and Longauill, Were Louers too, ill to example ill, Would from my forehead wipe a periur’d note: For none offend, where all alike doe dote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Dumaine, thy Loue is farre from charitie,
That in Loues griefe desir'st ſocietie:
You may looke pale, but I ſhould blush I know,
To be ore-heard, and taken napping ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, you blush: as his, your case is ſuch,
You chide at him, offending twice as much.
You doe not loue Maria? Longauile,
Did neuer Sonnet for her ſake compile;
Nor neuer lay his wreathed armes athwart
His louing bosome, to keepe downe his heart.
I haue beene closely ſhrowded in this bush,
And markt you both, and for you both did blush.
I heard your guilty Rimes, obseru’d your fashion:
Saw ſighes reeke from you, noted well your paſſion.
Aye me, ſayes one! O Ioue, the other cries!
On her haires were Gold, Christall the others eyes.
You would for Paradise breake Faith and troth,
And Ioue for your Loue would infringe an oath.
What will Berowne ſay when that he ſhall heare
Faith infringed, which ſuch zeale did ſweare.
How will he ſcorne? how will he ſpend his wit?
How will he triumph, leape, and laugh at it?
For all the wealth that euer I did ſee,
I would not haue him know ſo much by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſtep I forth to whip hypocrisie.
Ah good my Liedge, I pray thee pardon me.
Good heart, What grace hast thou thus to reproue
These wormes for louing, that art mo’t in loue?
Your eyes doe make no couches in your teares.
There is no certaine Princeſſe that appeares.
You'll not be periur’d, ‘tis a hatefull thing:
Tuſh, none but Minstrels like of Sonnetting.
But are you not asham’d? nay, are you not
All three of you, to be thus much ore'shot?
You found his Moth, the King your Moth did ſee:
But I a Beame doe finde in each of three.
O what a Scene of fool'ry haue I ſeene.
Of ſighes, of grones, of ſorrow, and of teene:
O me, with what ſtrict patience haue I ſat,
To ſee a King transformed to a Gnat?
To ſee great Hercules whipping a Gigge,
And profound Salomon tuning a Iygge?
And Nestor play at push-pin with the boyes,
And Critticke Tymon laugh at idle toyes.
Where lies thy griefe? O tell me good Dumaine;
And gentle Longauill, where lies thy paine?
And where my Liedges? all about the brest:
A Candle hoa!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Too bitter is thy iest.
Are wee betrayed thus to thy ouer-view?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Not you by me, but I betrayed to you. I that am honeſt, I that hold it ſinne To breake the vow I am ingaged in. I am betrayed by keeping company With men, like men of inconstancie. When ſhall you ſee me write a thing in rime? Or grone for Ioane? or ſpend a minutes time, In pruning mee, when ſhall you heare that I will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye: a gate, a ſtate, a brow, a brest, a waste, a legge, a limme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft, Whither a-way ſo fast?
A true man, or a theefe, that gallops ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I post from Loue, good Louer let me go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaqu.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What Present hast thou there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Some certaine treason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What makes treason heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay it makes nothing ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If it marre nothing neither,
The treason and you goe in peace away together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaqu.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech your Grace let this Letter be read,
Our person mis-doubts it: it was treason he ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne, read it ouer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where hadst thou it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iaqu.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Costard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Where hadst thou it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cost.
