SPEECH.LINE: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, what is in you? why dost thou tear it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A toy my Liedge, a toy: your grace needes not feare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: It did moue him to paſſion, and therefore let's heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: It is Berowns writing, and heere is his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah you whoreson loggerhead, you were borne to doe me ſhame. Guilty my Lord, guilty: I confeſſe, I confeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: That you three fooles, lackt mee foole, to make vp the meſſe. He, he, and you: and you my Liedge, and I, Are picke-purses in Loue, and we deserue to die. O dismiſſe this audience, and I ſhall tell you more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the number is euen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berow.
SPEECH.LINE: True true, we are fowre: will these Turtles be gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence ſirs, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Walk aside the true folke, & let the traytors ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Lords, ſweet Louers, O let vs imbrace,
As true we are as flesh and bloud can be,
The Sea will ebbe and flow, heauen will ſhew his face:
Young bloud doth not obey an old decree.
We cannot croſſe the cause why we are borne:
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What, did these rent lines ſhew ſome loue of thine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Did they, quoth you? Who ſees the heauenly Rosaline,
That (like a rude and ſauage man of Inde.)
At the first opening of the gorgeous East,
Bowes not his vaſſall head, and ſtrooken blinde,
Kiſſes the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory Eagle-sighted eye
Dares looke vpon the heauen of her brow,
That is not blinded by her maiestie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: What zeale, what furie, hath inspir’d thee now?
My Loue (her Mistres) is a gracious Moone,
Shee (an attending Starre) ſcarce ſeene a light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne.
O, but for my Loue, day would turne to night,
Of all complexions the cul’d ſoueraignty,
Doe meet as at a faire in her faire cheeke,
Where ſeuerall Worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants, that want it ſelfe doth ſeeke.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues,
Fie painted Rethoricke, O ſhe needs it not,
To things of ſale, a ſellers praise belongs:
She paſſes prayse, then prayse too ſhort doth blot.
A withered Hermite, fiuescore winters worne,
Might ſhake off fiftie, looking in her eye:
Beauty doth varnish Age, as if new borne,
And giues the Crutch the Cradles infancie.
O ‘tis the Sunne that maketh all things ſhine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen, thy Loue is blacke as Ebonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Berow.
SPEECH.LINE: Is Ebonie like her? O word diuine?
A wife of ſuch wood were felicite.
O who can giue an oth? Where is a booke?
That I may ſweare Beauty doth beauty lacke,
If that ſhe learne not of her eye to looke:
No face is faire that is not full ſo blacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: O paradoxe, Blacke is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons, and the Schoole of night:
And beauties crest becomes the heauens well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Diuels ſoonest tempt resembling ſpirits of light.
O if in blacke my Ladies browes be deckt,
It mournes, that painting vsurping haire
Should rauish doters with a false aspect:
And therfore is ſhe borne to make blacke, faire.
Her fauour turnes the fashion of the dayes,
For natiue bloud is counted painting now:
And therefore red that would auoyd dispraise,
Paints it ſelfe blacke, to imitate her brow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: To look like her are Chimny-sweepers blacke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſince her time, are Colliers counted bright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: And Aethiops of their ſweet complexion crake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Dark needs no Candles now, for dark is light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Your mistreſſes dare neuer come in raine,
For feare their colours ſhould be washt away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twere good yours did: for ſir to tell you plaine,
Ile finde a fairer face not washt to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile proue her faire, or talke till dooms-day here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: No Diuell will fright thee then ſo much as ſhee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duma.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer knew man hold vile ſtuffe ſo deere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, heer's thy loue, my foot and her face ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O if the ſtreets were paued with thine eyes,
Her feet were much too dainty for ſuch tread.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duma.
SPEECH.LINE: O vile, then as ſhe goes what vpward lyes?
The ſtreet ſhould ſee as ſhe walk’d ouer head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: But what of this, are we not all in loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O nothing ſo ſure, and thereby all forsworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then leaue this chat, & good Berown now proue
Our louing lawfull, and our fayth not torne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I marie there, ſome flattery for this euill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſome authority how to proceed,
Some tricks, ſome quillets, how to cheat the diuell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Some ſalue for periurie,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O ‘tis more then neede.
Haue at you then affections men at armes,
Consider what you first did ſweare vnto:
To fast, to ſtudy, and to ſee no woman:
Flat treason against the Kingly ſtate of youth.
Say, Can you fast? your ſtomacks are too young:
And abstinence ingenders maladies.
And where that you haue vow’d to ſtudie (Lords)
In that each of you haue forsworne his Booke.
Can you ſtill dreame and pore, and thereon looke.
For when would you my Lord, or you, or you,
Haue found the ground of ſtudies excellence,
Without the beauty of a womans face;
From womens eyes this doctrine I deriue,
They are the Ground, the Bookes, the Achadems,
From whence doth ſpring the true Promethean fire.
Why, vniuersall plodding poysons vp
The nimble ſpirits in the arteries,
As motion and long during action tyres
The ſinnowy vigour of the trauailer.
Now for not looking on a womans face,
You haue in that forsworne the vse of eyes:
And ſtudie too, the causer of your vow.
For where is any Author in the world,
Teaches ſuch beauty as a womans eye:
Learning is but an adiunct to our ſelfe,
And where we are, our Learning likewise is.
Then when our ſelues we ſee in Ladies eyes,
With our ſelues.
Doe we not likewise ſee our learning there?
O we haue made a Vow to ſtudie, Lords,
And in that vow we haue forsworne our Bookes:
For when would you (my Leege) or you, or you?
In leaden contemplation haue found out
Such fiery Numbers as the prompting eyes,
Of beauties tutors haue inrich’d you with:
Other ſlow Arts intirely keepe the braine:
And therefore finding barraine practizers,
Scarce ſhew a haruest of their heauy toyle.
But Loue first learned in a Ladies eyes,
Liues not alone emured in the braine:
But with the motion of all elements,
Courses as ſwift as thought in euery power,
And giues to euery power a double power,
Aboue their functions and their offices.
It addes a precious ſeeing to the eye:
A Louers eyes will gaze an Eagle blinde.
A Louers eare will heare the lowest ſound.
When the ſuspicious head of theft is ſtopt.
Loues feeling is more ſoft and ſensible,
Then are the tender hornes of Cockle Snayles.
Loues tongue proues dainty, Bachus groſſe in taste,
For Valour, is not Loue a Hercules?
Still climing trees in the Hesperides.
Subtill as Sphinx, as ſweet and musicall,
As bright Apollo's Lute, ſtrung with his haire.
And when Loue ſpeakes, the voyce of all the Gods,
Make heauen drowsie with the harmonie.
Neuer durst Pœt touch a pen to write,
Vntill his Inke were tempred with Loues ſighes:
O then his lines would rauish ſauage eares,
And plant in Tyrants milde humilitie.
From womens eyes this doctrine I deriue.
They ſparcle ſtill the right promethean fire,
They are the Bookes, the Arts, the Achademes,
That ſhew, containe, and nourish all the world.
Else none at all in ought proues excellent.
Then fooles you were these women to forsweare:
Or keeping what is ſworne, you will proue fooles,
For Wisedomes ſake, a word that all men loue:
Or for Loues ſake, a word that loues all men.
Or for Mens ſake, the author of these Women:
Or Womens ſake, by whom we men are Men.
Let's once loose our oathes to finde our ſelues,
Or else we loose our ſelues, to keepe our oathes:
It is religion to be thus forsworne.
For Charity it ſelfe fulfills the Law:
And who can ſeuer loue from Charity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Saint Cupid then, and Souldiers to the field.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Aduance your ſtandards, & vpon them Lords,
Pell, mell, downe with them: but be first aduis’d,
In conflict that you get the Sunne of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Now to plaine dealing, Lay these glozes by,
Shall we resolue to wœ these girles of France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: And winne them too, therefore let vs deuise,
Some entertainment for them in their Tents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: First from the Park let vs conduct them thither,
Then homeward euery man attach the hand
Of his faire Mistreſſe, in the afternoone
We will with ſome ſtrange pastime ſolace them:
Such as the ſhortneſſe of the time can ſhape,
For Reuels, Dances, Maskes, and merry houres,
Fore-runne faire Loue, ſtrewing her way with flowres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, away, no time ſhall be omitted,
That will be time, and may by vs be fitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Alone, alone ſowed Cockell, reap’d no Corne,
And Iustice alwaies whirles in equall measure:
Light Wenches may proue plagues to men forsworne,
If ſo, our Copper buyes no better treasure.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Pedant, Curate and Dull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pedant.
SPEECH.LINE: Satis quid ſufficit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: I praise God for you ſir, your reasons at dinner haue beene ſharpe & ſententious: pleasant without ſcur-rillity, witty without affection, audacious without im-pudency, learned without opinion, and ſtrange without heresie: I did conuerse this quondam day with a compa-nion of the Kings, who is intituled, nominated, or called, Don Adriano de Armatho.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Noui hominum tanquam te, His humour is lofty, his discourse peremptorie: his tongue filed, his eye ambitious, his gate maiesticall, and his generall behaui-our vaine, ridiculous, and thrasonicall. He is too picked, too ſpruce, too affected, too odde, as it were, too pere-grinat, as I may call it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t ſingular and choise Epithat,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: He draweth out the thred of his verbositie, fi-ner then the ſtaple of his argument. I abhor ſuch pha-naticall phantasims, ſuch insociable and poynt deuise companions, ſuch rackers of ortagriphie, as to ſpeake dout fine, when he ſhould ſay doubt; det, when he ſhold pronounce debt; debt, not det: he clepeth a Calf, Caufe: halfe, haufe: neighbour vocatur nebour; neigh abreuiated ne: this is abhominable, which he would call abhomi-nable it insinuateth me of infamie: ne inteligis domine, to make franticke, lunaticke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cura.
SPEECH.LINE: Laus deo, bene intelligo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Bome boon for boon prescian, a little ſcratcht, 'twil ſerue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: Vides ne quis venit?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Video, & gaudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Chirra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Quari Chirra, not Sirra?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Men of peace well incountred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t millitarie ſir ſalutation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They haue beene at a great feast of Languages, and ſtolne the ſcraps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O they haue liu’d long on the almes-basket of words. I maruell thy M[aster]. hath not eaten thee for a word, for thou art not ſo long by the head as honorificabilitu-%dinitatibus: Thou art easier ſwallowed then a flapdra-gon. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, the peale begins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Mounsier, are you not lettred?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, yes, he teaches boyes the Horne-booke:
What is Ab ſpeld backward with the horn on his head?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Ba, puericia with a horne added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Ba mo’t ſeely Sheepe, with a horne: you heare his learning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Quis quis, thou Consonant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: The last of the fiue Vowels if You repeat them, or the fift if I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I will repeat them: a e I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sheepe, the other two concludes it o u.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by the ſalt waue of the mediteranium, a ſweet tutch, a quicke venewe of wit, ſnip ſnap, quick & home, it reioyceth my intellect, true wit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Offered by a childe to an olde man: which is wit-old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the figure? What is the figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Hornes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou disputes like an Infant: goe whip thy
Gigge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Lend me your Horne to make one, and I will whip about your Infamie vnum cita a gigge of a Cuck-olds horne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: And I had but one penny in the world, thou ſhouldst haue it to buy Ginger bread: Hold, there is the very Remuneration I had of thy Maister, thou halfpenny purse of wit, thou Pidgeon-egge of discretion. O & the heauens were ſo pleased, that thou wert but my Bastard; What a ioyfull father wouldst thou make mee? Goe to, thou hast it ad dungil, at the fingers ends, as they ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I ſmell false Latine, dunghel for vnguem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Arts-man preambulat, we will bee ſingled from the barbarous. Do you not educate youth at the Charg-house on the top of the Mountaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Or Mons the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: At your ſweet pleasure, for the Mountaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe ſans question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bra.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, it is the Kings mo’t ſweet pleasure and af-fection, to congratulate the Princeſſe at her Pauilion, in the posteriors of this day, which the rude multitude call the after-noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: The posterior of the day, mo’t generous ſir, is lia-ble, congruent, and measurable for the after-noone: the word is well culd, chose, ſweet, and apt I doe aſſure you ſir, I doe aſſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the King is a noble Gentleman, and my fa-miliar, I doe aſſure ye very good friend: for what is in-ward betweene vs, let it paſſe. I doe beseech thee re-member thy curtesie. I beseech thee apparell thy head: and among other importunate & mo’t ſerious designes, and of great import indeed too: but let that paſſe, for I must tell thee it will please his Grace (by the world) ſometime to leane vpon my poore ſhoulder, and with his royall finger thus dallie with my excrement, with my mustachio: but ſweet heart let that paſſe. By the world I recount no fable, ſome certaine ſpeciall honours it pleaseth his greatneſſe to impart to Armado a Souldier, a man of trauell, that hath ſeene the world: but let that paſſe; the very all of all is: but ſweet heart I do implore ſecrecie, that the King would haue mee present the Princeſſe (sweet chucke) with ſome delightfull ostenta-tion, or ſhow, or pageant, or anticke, or fire-worke: Now, vnderstanding that the Curate and your ſweet ſelf are good at ſuch eruptions, and ſodaine breaking out of myrth (as it were) I haue acquainted you withall, to the end to craue your aſſistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you ſhall present before her the Nine Wor-thies. Sir Holofernes, as concerning ſome entertainment of time, ſome ſhow in the posterior of this day, to bee rendred by our aſſistants the Kings command: and this mo’t gallant, illustrate and learned Gentleman, before the Princeſſe: I ſay none ſo fit as to present the Nine Worthies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Curat.
SPEECH.LINE: Where will you finde men worthy enough to present them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Iosua, your ſelfe: my ſelfe, and this gallant gen-tleman Iudas Machabeus; this Swaine (because of his great limme or ioynt) ſhall paſſe Pompey the great, the Page Hercules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon ſir, error: He is not quantitie enough for that Worthies thumb, hee is not ſo big as the end of his Club.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I haue audience: he ſhall present Hercu-les in minoritie: his enter and exit ſhall bee ſtrangling a Snake; and I will haue an Apologie for that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: An excellent deuice: ſo if any of the audience hiſſe, you may cry, Well done Hercules, now thou cru-shest the Snake; that is the way to make an offence gra-cious, though few haue the grace to doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: For the rest of the Worthies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: I will play three my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Thrice worthy Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I tell you a thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peda.
SPEECH.LINE: We attend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: We will haue, if this fadge not, an Antique. I beseech you follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Via good-man Dull, thou hast ſpoken no word all this while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dull.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor vnderstood none neither ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Alone, we will employ thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dull.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make one in a dance, or ſo: or I will play on the taber to the Worthies, & let them dance the hey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t Dull, honeſt Dull, to our ſport away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet hearts we ſhall be rich ere we depart, If fairings come thus plentifully in. A Lady wal’d about with Diamonds: Look you, what I haue from the louing King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, came nothing else along with that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but this: yes as much loue in Rime,
As would be cram’d vp in a ſheet of paper
Writ on both ſides the leafe, margent and all,
That he was faine to ſeale on Cupids name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: That was the way to make his god-head wax:
For he hath beene fiue thousand yeeres a Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and a ſhrewd vnhappy gallowes too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: You'll nere be friends with him, a kild your ſister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: He made her melancholy, ſad, and heauy, and ſo ſhe died: had ſhe beene Light like you, of ſuch a mer-rie nimble ſtirring ſpirit, ſhe might a bin a Grandam ere ſhe died. And ſo may you: For a light heart liues long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your darke meaning mouse, of this light word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: A light condition in a beauty darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: We need more light to finde your meaning out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: You'll marre the light by taking it in ſnuffe:
Therefore Ile darkely end the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Look what you doe, you doe it ſtil i'th darke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: So do not you, for you are a light Wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed I waigh not you, and therefore light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka.
SPEECH.LINE: You waigh me not, O that’s you care not for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Great reason: for past care, is ſtill past cure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Well bandied both, a ſet of Wit well played.
But Rosaline, you haue a Fauour too?
Who ſent it? and what is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: I would you knew.
And if my face were but as faire as yours,
My Fauour were as great, be witneſſe this.
Nay, I haue Verses too, I thanke Berowne,
The numbers true, and were the numbring too.
I were the fairest goddeſſe on the ground.
I am compar’d to twenty thousand fairs.
O he hath drawne my picture in his letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Any thing like?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Much in the letters, nothing in the praise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Beauteous as Incke: a good conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire as a text B. in a Coppie booke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Ware pensals. How? Let me not die your debtor,
My red Dominicall, my golden letter.
O that your face were full of Oes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A Pox of that iest, and I beshrew all Shrowes:
But Katherine, what was ſent to you
From faire Dumaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, this Gloue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Did he not ſend you twaine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes Madame: and moreouer,
Some thousand Verses of a faithfull Louer.
A huge translation of hypocrisie,
Vildly compiled, profound ſimplicitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: This, and these Pearls, to me ſent Longauile.
The Letter is too long by halfe a mile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke no leſſe: Dost thou wish in heart
The Chaine were longer, and the Letter ſhort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or I would these hands might neuer part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: We are wise girles to mocke our Louers ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: They are worse fooles to purchase mocking ſo.
That ſame Berowne ile torture ere I goe.
O that I knew he were but in by th’ weeke,
How I would make him fawne, and begge, and ſeeke,
And wait the ſeason, and obserue the times,
And ſpend his prodigall wits in booteles rimes,
And ſhape his ſeruice wholly to my deuice,
And make him proud to make me proud that iests.
So pertaunt like would I o’resway his ſtate,
That he ſhold be my foole, and I his fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: None are ſo ſurely caught, when they are catcht,
As Wit turn’d foole, follie in Wisedome hatch’d:
Hath wisedoms warrant, and the helpe of Schoole,
And Wits owne grace to grace a learned Foole?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: The bloud of youth burns not with ſuch exceſſe,
As grauities reuolt to wantons be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Follie in Fooles beares not ſo ſtrong a note,
As fool'ry in the Wise, when Wit doth dote:
Since all the power thereof it doth apply,
To proue by Wit, worth in ſimplicitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere comes Boyet, and mirth in his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: O I am ſtab’d with laughter, Wher's her Grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy newes Boyet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare Madame, prepare.
Arme Wenches arme, incounters mounted are,
Against your Peace, Loue doth approach, disguis’d:
Armed in arguments, you'll be ſurpriz’d.
Muster your Wits, ſtand in your owne defence,
Or hide your heads like Cowards, and flie hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Saint Dennis to S[aint]. Cupid: What are they,
That charge their breath against vs? Say ſcout ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder the coole ſhade of a Siccamore,
I thought to close mine eyes ſome halfe an houre:
When lo to interrupt my purpos’d rest,
Toward that ſhade I might behold addrest,
The King and his companions: warely
I ſtole into a neighbour thicket by,
And ouer-heard, what you ſhall ouer-heare:
That by and by disguis’d they will be heere.
Their Herald is a pretty knauish Page:
That well by heart hath con’d his embaſſage,
Action and accent did they teach him there.
Thus must thou ſpeake, and thus thy body beare.
And euer and anon they made a doubt,
Presence maiesticall would put him out:
For quoth the King, an Angell ſhalt thou ſee:
Yet feare not thou, but ſpeake audaciously.
The Boy reply’d, An Angell is not euill:
I ſhould haue fear’d her, had ſhe beene a deuill.
With that all laugh’d, and clap’d him on the ſhoulder,
Making the bold wagg by their praises bolder.
One rub’d his elbœ thus, and fleer’d, and ſwore,
A better ſpeech was neuer ſpoke before.
Another with his finger and his thumb,
Cry’d via, we will doo't, come what will come.
The third he caper’d and cried, All goes well.
The fourth turn’d on the tœ, and downe he fell:
With that they all did tumble on the ground,
With ſuch a zelous laughter ſo profound,
That in this ſpleene ridiculous appeares,
To checke their folly paſſions ſolemne teares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: But what, but what, come they to visit vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They do, they do; and are apparel’d thus,
Like Muscouites; or Ruſſians, as I geſſe.
Their purpose is to parlee, to court, and dance,
And euery one his Loue-feat will aduance,
Vnto his ſeuerall mistreſſe: which they'll know
By fauours ſeuerall, which they did bestow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: And will they ſo? the Gallants ſhall be taskt:
For Ladies; we will euery one be maskt,
And not a man of them ſhall haue the grace
Despight of ſute, to ſee a Ladies face.
Hold Rosaline, this Fauour thou ſhalt weare,
And then the King will court thee for his Deare:
Hold, take thou this my ſweet, and giue me thine,
So ſhall Berowne take me for Rosaline.
And change your Fauours too, ſo ſhall your Loues
Woo contrary, deceiu’d by these remoues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on then, weare the fauours mo’t in ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: But in this changing, What is your intent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: The effect of my intent is to croſſe theirs:
They doe it but in mocking merriment,
And mocke for mocke is onely my intent.
Their ſeuerall counsels they vnbosome ſhall,
To Loues mistooke, and ſo be mockt withall.
Vpon the next occasion that we meete,
With Visages displayd to talke and greete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall we dance, if they desire vs too't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: No, to the death we will not moue a foot,
Nor to their pen’d ſpeech render we no grace:
But while ‘tis ſpoke, each turne away his face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that contempt will kill the keepers heart,
And quite diuorce his memory from his part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore I doe it, and I make no doubt,
The rest will ere come in, if he be out.
Theres no ſuch ſport, as ſport by ſport orethrowne:
To make theirs ours, and ours none but our owne.
So ſhall we ſtay mocking entended game,
And they well mockt, depart away with ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: The Trompet ſounds, be maskt, the maskers come.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Black moores with musicke, the Boy with a ſpeech, and the rest of the Lords disguised

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: All haile, the richest Beauties on the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Beauties no richer then rich Taffata.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: A holy parcell of the fairest dames that euer turn’d their backes to mortall viewes.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The Ladies turne their backes to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Their eyes villaine, their eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: That euer turn’d their eyes to mortall viewes.
Out

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: True, out indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Out of your fauours heauenly ſpirits vouchsafe
Not to beholde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Once to behold, rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: Once to behold with your Sunne beamed eyes,
With your Sunne beamed eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They will not anſwer to that Epythite, you were best call it Daughter beamed eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pag.
SPEECH.LINE: They do not marke me, and that brings me out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this your perfectneſſe? be gon you rogue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: What would these ſtrangers?
Know their mindes Boyet.
If they doe ſpeake our language, ‘tis our will
That ſome plaine man recount their purposes.
Know what they would?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: What would you with the Princes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: What would they, ſay they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but peace, and gentle visitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that they haue, and bid them ſo be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſaies you haue it, and you may be gon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Say to her we haue measur’d many miles,
To tread a Measure with you on the graſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay that they haue measur’d many a mile,
To tread a Measure with you on this graſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſo. Aske them how many inches
Is in one mile? If they haue measur’d manie,
The measure then of one is easlie told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: If to come hither, you haue measur’d miles,
And many miles: the Princeſſe bids you tell,
How many inches doth fill vp one mile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell her we measure them by weary ſteps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: She heares her ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: How manie wearie ſteps,
Of many wearie miles you haue ore-gone,
Are numbred in the trauell of one mile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bero.
SPEECH.LINE: We number nothing that we ſpend for you,
Our dutie is ſo rich, ſo infinite,
That we may doe it ſtill without accompt.
Vouchsafe to ſhew the ſunshine of your face,
That we (like ſauages) may worship it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: My face is but a Moone and clouded too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſed are clouds, to doe as ſuch clouds do.
Vouchsafe bright Moone, and these thy ſtars to ſhine,
(Those clouds remooued) vpon our waterie eyne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: O vaine peticioner, beg a greater matter,
Thou now requests but Mooneshine in the water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then in our measure, vouchsafe but one change.
Thou bidst me begge, this begging is not ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Play musicke then: nay you must doe it ſoone.
Not yet no dance: thus change I like the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you not dance? How come you thus e-stranged?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: You tooke the Moone at full, but now ſhee's changed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſtill ſhe is the Moone, and I the Man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: The musick playes, vouchsafe ſome motion to it: Our eares vouchsafe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: But your legges ſhould doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Since you are ſtrangers, & come here by chance,
Wee'll not be nice, take hands, we will not dance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why take you hands then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Onelie to part friends.
Curtsie ſweet hearts, and ſo the Measure ends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: More measure of this measure, be not nice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: We can afford no more at ſuch a price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Prise your ſelues: What buyes your companie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Your absence onelie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: That can neuer be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Then cannot we be bought: and ſo adue,
Twice to your Visore, and halfe once to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If you denie to dance, let's hold more chat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: In priuate then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I am best pleas’d with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Be.
SPEECH.LINE: White handed Mistris, one ſweet word with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hony, and Milke, and Suger: there is three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then two treyes, an if you grow ſo nice
Methegline, Wort, and Malmsey; well runne dice:
There's halfe a dozen ſweets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuenth ſweet adue, ſince you can cogg,
Ile play no more with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: One word in ſecret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it not be ſweet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou greeu'st my gall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Gall, bitter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you vouchsafe with me to change a word?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Name it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Ladie:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you ſo? Faire Lord:
Take you that for your faire Lady.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Please it you,
As much in priuate, and Ile bid adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: What, was your vizard made without a tong?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: I know the reason Ladie why you aske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: O for your reason, quickly ſir, I long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue a double tongue within your mask,
And would affoord my ſpeechleſſe vizard halfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Veale quoth the Dutch-man: is not Veale a
Calfe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: A Calfe faire Ladie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No, a faire Lord Calfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's part the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Ile not be your halfe:
Take all and weane it, it may proue an Oxe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke how you but your ſelfe in these ſharpe mockes. Will you giue hornes chast Ladie? Do not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Then die a Calfe before your horns do grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: One word in priuate with you ere I die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleat ſoftly then, the Butcher heares you cry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: The tongues of mocking wenches are as keen
As is the Razors edge, inuisible:
Cutting a ſmaller haire then may be ſeene,
Aboue the ſense of ſence ſo ſensible:
Seemeth their conference, their conceits haue wings,
Fleeter then arrows, bullets wind, thoght, ſwifter things

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Not one word more my maides, breake off, breake off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen, all drie beaten with pure ſcoffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell madde Wenches, you haue ſimple wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Twentie adieus my frozen Muscouits.
Are these the breed of wits ſo wondred at?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Tapers they are, with your ſweete breathes puft out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel-liking wits they haue, groſſe, groſſe, fat, fat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: O pouertie in wit, Kingly poore flout.
Will they not (thinke you) hang themselues to night?
Or euer but in vizards ſhew their faces:
This pert Berowne was out of count'nance quite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: They were all in lamentable cases.
The King was weeping ripe for a good word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne did ſweare himselfe out of all ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Dumaine was at my ſeruice, and his ſword:
No point (quoth I:) my ſeruant ſtraight was mute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ka.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Longauill ſaid I came ore his hart:
And trow you what he call’d me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Qualme perhaps.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes in good faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſickneſſe as thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, better wits haue worne plain ſtatute caps,
But will you heare; the King is my loue ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And quicke Berowne hath plighted faith to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: And Longauill was for my ſeruice borne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Dumaine is mine as ſure as barke on tree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, and prettie mistreſſes giue eare,
Immediately they will againe be heere
In their owne ſhapes: for it can neuer be,
They will digest this harsh indignitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Will they returne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: They will they will, God knowes,
And leape for ioy, though they are lame with blowes:
Therefore change Fauours, and when they repaire,
Blow like ſweet Roses, in this ſummer aire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How blow? how blow? Speake to bee vnder-stood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Ladies maskt, are Roses in their bud:
Dismaskt, their damaske ſweet commixture ſhowne,
Are Angels vailing clouds, or Roses blowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Auant perplexitie: What ſhall we do,
If they returne in their owne ſhapes to wo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam, if by me you'l be aduis’d.
Let's mocke them ſtill as well knowne as disguis’d:
Let vs complaine to them what fooles were heare,
Disguis’d like Muscouites in ſhapeleſſe geare:
And wonder what they were, and to what end
Their ſhallow ſhowes, and Prologue vildely pen’d:
And their rough carriage ſo ridiculous,
Should be presented at our Tent to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boyet.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladies, withdraw: the gallants are at hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quee.
SPEECH.LINE: Whip to our Tents, as Rœs runnes ore Land.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the King and the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire ſir, God ſaue you. Wher's the Princeſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Gone to her Tent.
Please it your Maiestie command me any ſeruice to her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhe vouchsafe me audience for one word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy
SPEECH.LINE: I will, and ſo will ſhe, I know my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This fellow pickes vp wit as Pigeons pease,
And vtters it againe, when Ioue doth please.
He is Wits Pedler, and retailes his Wares,
At Wakes, and Waſſels, Meetings, Markets, Faires.
And we that ſell by groſſe, the Lord doth know,
Haue not the grace to grace it with ſuch ſhow.
This Gallant pins the Wenches on his ſleeue.
Had he bin Adam, he had tempted Eue.
He can carue too, and lispe: Why this is he,
That kist away his hand in courtesie.
This is the Ape of Forme, Monsieur the nice,
That when he plaies at Tables, chides the Dice
In honorable tearmes: Nay he can ſing
A meane mo’t meanly, and in Vshering
Mend him who can: the Ladies call him ſweete.
The ſtaires as he treads on them kiſſe his feete.
This is the flower that ſmiles on euerie one,
To ſhew his teeth as white as Whales bone.
And consciences that wil not die in debt,
Pay him the dutie of honie-tongued Boyet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: A blister on his ſweet tongue with my hart,
That put Armathœs Page out of his part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: See where it comes. Behauiour what wer't thou,
Till this madman ſhew’d thee? And what art thou now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: All haile ſweet Madame, and faire time of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire in all Haile is foule, as I conceiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Construe my ſpeeches better, if you may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Then wish me better, I wil giue you leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We came to visit you, and purpose now
To leade you to our Court, vouchsafe it then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: This field ſhal hold me, and ſo hold your vow:
Nor God, nor I, delights in periur’d men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Rebuke me not for that which you prouoke:
The vertue of your eie must breake my oth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Q.
SPEECH.LINE: You nickname vertue: vice you ſhould haue ſpoke:
For vertues office neuer breakes men troth.
Now by my maiden honor, yet as pure
As the vnsallied Lilly, I protest,
A world of torments though I ſhould endure,
I would not yeeld to be your houses guest:
So much I hate a breaking cause to be
Of heauenly oaths, vow’d with integritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: O you haue liu’d in desolation heere,
Vnseene, vnuisited, much to our ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord, it is not ſo I ſweare,
We haue had pastimes heere, and pleasant game,
A meſſe of Ruſſians left vs but of late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How Madam? Ruſſians?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I in truth, my Lord.
Trim gallants, full of Courtship and of ſtate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam ſpeake true. It is not ſo my Lord:
My Ladie (to the manner of the daies)
In curtesie giues vndeseruing praise.
We foure indeed confronted were with foure
In Ruſſia habit: Heere they ſtayed an houre,
And talk’d apace: and in that houre (my Lord)
They did not bleſſe vs with one happy word.
I dare not call them fooles; but this I thinke,
When they are thirstie, fooles would faine haue drinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This iest is drie to me. Gentle ſweete,
Your wits makes wise things foolish when we greete
With eies best ſeeing, heauens fierie eie:
By light we loose light; your capacitie
Is of that nature, that to your huge ſtoore,
Wise things ſeeme foolish, and rich things but poore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: This proues you wise and rich: for in my eie

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a foole, and full of pouertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: But that you take what doth to you belong,
It were a fault to ſnatch words from my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: O, I am yours, and all that I poſſeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: All the foole mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot giue you leſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Which of the Vizards what it that you wore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Where? when? What Vizard?
Why demand you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: There, then, that vizard, that ſuperfluous case,
That hid the worse, and ſhew’d the better face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: We are discried,
They'l mocke vs now downeright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs confeſſe, and turne it to a iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: Amaz’d my Lord? Why lookes your Highnes ſadde?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Helpe hold his browes, hee'l ſound: why looke you pale? Sea-sicke I thinke comming from Muscouie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus poure the ſtars down plagues for periury.
Can any face of braſſe hold longer out?
Heere ſtand I, Ladie dart thy ſkill at me,
Bruise me with ſcorne, confound me with a flout.
Thrust thy ſharpe wit quite through my ignorance.
Cut me to peeces with thy keene conceit:
And I will wish thee neuer more to dance,
Nor neuer more in Ruſſian habit waite.
O! neuer will I trust to ſpeeches pen’d,
Nor to the motion of a Schoole-boies tongue.
Nor neuer come in vizard to my friend,
Nor woo in rime like a blind-harpers ſongue,
Taffata phrases, ſilken tearmes precise,
Three-pil’d Hyperboles, ſpruce affection;
Figures pedanticall, these ſummer flies,
Haue blowne me full of maggot ostentation.
I do forsweare them, and I heere protest,
By this white Gloue (how white the hand God knows)
Henceforth my woing minde ſhall be exprest
In ruſſet yeas, and honeſt kersie nœs.
And to begin Wench, ſo God helpe me law,
My loue to thee is ſound, ſans cracke or flaw,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sans, ſans, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet I haue a tricke
Of the old rage: beare with me, I am ſicke.
Ile leaue it by degrees: ſoft, let vs ſee,
Write Lord haue mercie on vs, on those three,
They are infected, in their hearts it lies:
They haue the plague, and caught it of your eyes:
These Lords are visited, you are not free:
For the Lords tokens on you do I ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: No, they are free that gaue these tokens to vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our ſtates are forfeit, ſeeke not to vndo vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſo; for how can this be true,
That you ſtand forfeit, being those that ſue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, for I will not haue to do with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor ſhall not, if I do as I intend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake for your ſelues, my wit is at an end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Teach vs ſweete Madame, for our rude trans-greſſion, ſome faire excuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The fairest is confeſſion.
Were you not heere but euen now, disguis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: And were you well aduis’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I was faire Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: When you then were heere,
What did you whisper in your Ladies eare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: That more then all the world I did respect her

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: When ſhee ſhall challenge this, you will reiect her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine Honor no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, peace, forbeare:
Your oath once broke, you force not to forsweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Despise me when I breake this oath of mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I will, and therefore keepe it. Rosaline,
What did the Ruſſian whisper in your eare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, he ſwore that he did hold me deare
As precious eye-ſight, and did value me
Aboue this World: adding thereto moreouer,
That he would Wed me, or else die my Louer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: God giue thee ioy of him: the Noble Lord
Mo’t honorably doth vphold his word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you Madame?
By my life, my troth
I neuer ſwore this Ladie ſuch an oth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen you did; and to confirme it plaine,
You gaue me this: But take it ſir againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: My faith and this, the Princeſſe I did giue,
I knew her by this Iewell on her ſleeue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me ſir, this Iewell did ſhe weare.
And Lord Berowne (I thanke him) is my deare.
What? Will you haue me, or your Pearle againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither of either, I remit both twaine.
I ſee the tricke on't: Heere was a consent,
Knowing aforehand of our merriment,
To dash it like a Christmas Comedie.
Some carry-tale, ſome please-man, ſome ſlight Zanie,
Some mumble-newes, ſome trencher-knight, ſom Dick
That ſmiles his cheeke in yeares, and knowes the trick
To make my Lady laugh, when ſhe's dispos’d;
Told our intents before: which once disclos’d,
The Ladies did change Fauours; and then we
Following the ſignes, woo’d but the ſigne of ſhe.
Now to our periurie, to adde more terror,
We are againe forsworne in will and error.
Much vpon this tis: and might not you
Forestall our ſport, to make vs thus vntrue?
Do not you know my Ladies foot by'th ſquier?
And laugh vpon the apple of her eie?
And ſtand betweene her backe ſir, and the fire,
Holding a trencher, iesting merrilie?
You put our Page out: go, you are alowd.
Die when you will, a ſmocke ſhall be your ſhrowd.
You leere vpon me, do you? There's an eie
Wounds like a Leaden ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Full merrily hath this braue manager, this car-reere bene run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Lœ, he is tilting ſtraight. Peace, I haue don.
Welcome pure wit, thou part'st a faire fray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, they would kno,
Whether the three worthies ſhall come in, or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are there but three?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, but it is vara fine,
For euerie one pursents three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And three times thrice is nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo ſir, vnder correction ſir, I hope it is not ſo. You cannot beg vs ſir, I can aſſure you ſir, we know what we know: I hope ſir three times thrice ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder correction ſir, wee know where-vntill it doth amount.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: By Ioue, I alwaies tooke three threes for nine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, it were pittie you ſhould get your liuing by reckning ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: How much is it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O Lord ſir, the parties themselues, the actors ſir will ſhew where-vntill it doth amount: for mine owne part, I am (as they ſay, but to perfect one man in one poore man) Pompion the great ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou one of the Worthies?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It pleased them to thinke me worthie of Pompey the great: for mine owne part, I know not the degree of the Worthie, but I am to ſtand for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber
SPEECH.LINE: Go, bid them prepare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: We will turne it finely off ſir, we wil take ſome care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Berowne, they will ſhame vs:
Let them not approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: We are ſhame-proofe my Lord: and ‘tis ſome policie, to haue one ſhew worse then the Kings and his companie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay they ſhall not come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay my good Lord, let me ore-rule you now;
That ſport best pleases, that doth least know how.
Where Zeale ſtriues to content, and the contents
Dies in the Zeale of that which it presents:
Their forme confounded, makes mo’t forme in mirth,
When great things labouring perish in their birth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A right description of our ſport my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Annointed, I implore ſo much expence of thy royall ſweet breath, as will vtter a brace of words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth this man ſerue God?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Why aske you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſpeak's not like a man of God's making.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: That's all one my faire ſweet honie Monarch: For I protest, the Schoolmaster is exceeding fantasticall: Too too vaine, too too vaine. But we wil put it (as they ſay) to Fortuna delaguar, I wish you the peace of minde mo’t royall cupplement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is like to be a good presence of Worthies; He presents Hector of Troy, the Swaine Pompey y great, the Parish Curate Alexander, Armadœs Page Hercules, the Pedant Iudas Machabeus: and if these foure Wor-thies in their first ſhew thriue, these foure will change habites, and present the other fiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: There is fiue in the first ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: You are deceiued, tis not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: The Pedant, the Braggart, the Hedge-Priest, the
Foole, and the Boy,
Abate throw at Novum, and the whole world againe,
Cannot pricke out fiue ſuch, take each one in's vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſhip is vnder ſaile, and here ſhe coms amain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I Pompey am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: You lie, you are not he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I Pompey am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: With Libbards head on knee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid old mocker,
I must needs be friends with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I Pompey am, Pompey ſurnam’d the big.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: The great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It is great ſir: Pompey ſurnam’d the great: That oft in field, with Targe and Shield, did make my fœ to ſweat: And trauailing along this coast, I heere am come by chance, And lay my Armes before the legs of this ſweet Laſſe of France. If your Ladiship would ſay thankes Pompey, I had done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: Great thankes great Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis not ſo much worth: but I hope I was per-fect.
I made a little fault in great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: My hat to a halfe-penie, Pompey prooues the best Worthie.

SCENE.SPEECH: Curat. When in the world I liu’d, I was the worldes Com-mander: _ By East, West, North, & South, I ſpred my conquering might My Scutcheon plaine declares that I am Alisander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boiet.
SPEECH.LINE: Your nose ſaies no, you are not:
For it ſtands too right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Your nose ſmells no, in this mo’t tender ſmel-ling
Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The Conqueror is dismaid:
Proceede good Alexander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cur.
SPEECH.LINE: When in the world I liued, I was the worldes Com-mander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boiet.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t true, ‘tis right; you were ſo Alisander.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey the great.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: your ſeruant and Costard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Take away the Conqueror, take away Alisander

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſir, you haue ouerthrowne Alisander the con-queror: you will be ſcrap’d out of the painted cloth for this: your Lion that holds his Pollax ſitting on a close ſtoole, will be giuen to Aiax. He will be the ninth wor-thie. A Conqueror, and affraid to ſpeake? Runne away for ſhame Alisander. There an't ſhall please you: a foo-lish milde man, an honeſt man, looke you, & ſoon dasht. He is a maruellous good neighbour insooth, and a verie good Bowler: but for Alisander, alas you ſee, how ‘tis a little ore-parted. But there are Worthies a comming, will ſpeake their minde in ſome other ſort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand aside good Pompey.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Pedant for Iudas, and the Boy for Hercules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Great Hercules is presented by this Impe,
Whose Club kil’d Cerberus that three-headed Canus,
And when he was a babe, a childe, a ſhrimpe,
Thus did he ſtrangle Serpents in his Manus:
Quoniam, he ſeemeth in minoritie,
Ergo, I come with this Apologie.
Keepe ſome ſtate in thy exit, and vanish. Exit Boy

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudas I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: A Iudas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Not Iscariot ſir.
Iudas I am, ycliped Machabeus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudas Machabeus clipt, is plaine Iudas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A kiſſing traitor. How art thou prou’d Iudas?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudas I am.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The more ſhame for you Iudas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What meane you ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: To make Iudas hang himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: Begin ſir, you are my elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Well follow’d, Iudas was hang’d on an Elder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not be put out of countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Because thou hast no face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: What is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: A Citterne head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The head of a bodkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A deaths face in a ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: The face of an old Roman coine, ſcarce ſeene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: The pummell of Caesars Faulchion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The caru’d-bone face on a Flaske.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: S[aint]. Georges halfe cheeke in a brooch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and in a brooch of Lead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and worne in the cap of a Tooth-drawer.
And now forward, for we haue put thee in countenance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue put me out of countenance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: False, we haue giuen thee faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: But you haue out-fac’d them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou wer't a Lion, we would do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore as he is, an Aſſe, let him go:
And ſo adieu ſweet Iude. Nay, why dost thou ſtay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: For the latter end of his name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: For the Aſſe to the Iude: giue it him. Iud-as a-way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ped.
SPEECH.LINE: This is not generous, not gentle, not humble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: A light for monsieur Iudas, it growes darke, he may ſtumble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Que.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Machabeus, how hath hee beene baited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Hide thy head Achilles, heere comes Hector in
Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Though my mockes come home by me, I will now be merrie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector was but a Troyan in respect of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: But is this Hector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke Hector was not ſo cleane timber’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: His legge is too big for Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: More Calfe certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: No, he is best indued in the ſmall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: This cannot be Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: He's a God or a Painter, for he makes faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Armipotent Mars, of Launces the almighty, gaue Hector a gift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: A gilt Nutmegge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A Lemmon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Stucke with Cloues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: No clouen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Armipotent Mars of Launces the almighty,
Gaue Hector a gift, the heire of Illion;
A man ſo breathed, that certaine he would fight: yea
From morne till night, out of his Pauillion.
I am that Flower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: That Mint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Long.
SPEECH.LINE: That Cullambine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Lord Longauill reine thy tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: I must rather giue it the reine: for it runnes a-gainst
Hector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Hector's a Grey-hound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſweet War-man is dead and rotten,
Sweet chuckes, beat not the bones of the buried:
But I will forward with my deuice;
Sweete Royaltie bestow on me the ſence of hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake braue Hector, we are much delighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: i do adore thy ſweet Graces ſlipper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: Loues her by the foot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: He may not by the yard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: This Hector farre ſurmounted Hanniball.
The partie is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow Hector, ſhe is gone; ſhe is two moneths on her way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanest thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith vnleſſe you play the honeſt Troyan, the poore Wench is cast away: ſhe's quick, the child brags in her belly alreadie: tis yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Dost thou infamonize me among Potentates?
Thou ſhalt die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſhall Hector be whipt for Iaquenetta that is quicke by him, and hang’d for Pompey, that is dead by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t rare Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boi.
SPEECH.LINE: Renowned Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Greater then great, great, great, great Pompey:
Pompey the huge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector trembles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey is moued, more Atees more Atees ſtirre them, or ſtirre them on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Hector will challenge him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if a'haue no more mans blood in's belly, then will ſup a Flea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: By the North-pole I do challenge thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil not fight with a pole like a Northern man; Ile ſlash, Ile do it by the ſword: I pray you let mee bor-row my Armes againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Roome for the incensed Worthies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile do it in my ſhirt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t resolute Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Page.
SPEECH.LINE: Master, let me take you a button hole lower: Do you not ſee Pompey is vncasing for the combat: what meane you? you will lose your reputation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen and Souldiers pardon me, I will not combat in my ſhirt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: You may not denie it, Pompey hath made the challenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet bloods, I both may, and will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: What reason haue you for't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The naked truth of it is, I haue no ſhirt,
I go woolward for penance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boy.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and it was inioyned him in Rome for want of Linnen: ſince when, Ile be ſworne he wore none, but a dishclout of Iaquenettas, and that hee weares next his heart for a fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you Madame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome Marcade, but that thou interruptest our merriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marc.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorrie Madam, for the newes I bring is heauie in my tongue. The King your father

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead for my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo: My tale is told.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Worthies away, the Scene begins to cloud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: For mine owne part, I breath free breath: I haue ſeene the day of wrong, through the little hole of discretion, and I will right my ſelfe like a Souldier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: How fare's your Maiestie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Boyet prepare, I will away to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame not ſo, I do beseech you ſtay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Prepare I ſay. I thanke you gracious Lords
For all your faire endeuours and entreats:
Out of a new ſad-soule, that you vouchsafe,
In your rich wisedome to excuse, or hide,
The liberall opposition of our ſpirits,
If ouer-boldly we haue borne our ſelues,
In the conuerse of breath (your gentleneſſe
Was guiltie of it.) Farewell worthie Lord:
A heauie heart beares not a humble tongue.
Excuse me ſo, comming ſo ſhort of thankes,
For my great ſuite, ſo easily obtain’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The extreme parts of time, extremelie formes
All causes to the purpose of his ſpeed:
And often at his verie loose decides
That, which long proceſſe could not arbitrate.
And though the mourning brow of progenie
Forbid the ſmiling curtesie of Loue:
The holy ſuite which faine it would conuince,
Yet ſince loues argument was first on foote,
Let not the cloud of ſorrow iustle it
From what it purpos’d: ſince to waile friends lost,
Is not by much ſo wholsome profitable,
As to reioyce at friends but newly found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I vnderstand you not, my greefes are double.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Honest plain words, best pierce the ears of griefe
And by these badges vnderstand the King,
For your faire ſakes haue we neglected time,
Plaid foule play with our oaths: your beautie Ladies
Hath much deformed vs, fashioning our humors
Euen to the opposed end of our intents.
And what in vs hath ſeem’d ridiculous:
As Loue is full of vnbefitting ſtraines,
All wanton as a childe, ſkipping and vaine.
Form’d by the eie, and therefore like the eie.
Full of ſtraying ſhapes, of habits, and of formes
Varying in ſubiects as the eie doth roule,
To euerie varied obiect in his glance:
Which partie-coated presence of loose loue
Put on by vs, if in your heauenly eies,
Haue misbecom’d our oathes and grauities.
Those heauenlie eies that looke into these faults,
Suggested vs to make: therefore Ladies
Our loue being yours, the error that Loue makes
Is likewise yours. We to our ſelues proue false,
By being once false, for euer to be true
To those that make vs both, faire Ladies you.
And euen that falshood in it ſelfe a ſinne,
Thus purifies it ſelfe, and turnes to grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue receiu’d your Letters, full of Loue:
Your Fauours, the Ambaſſadors of Loue.
And in our maiden counsaile rated them,
At courtship, pleasant iest, and curtesie,
As bumbast and as lining to the time:
But more deuout then these are our respects
Haue we not bene, and therefore met your loues
In their owne fashion, like a merriment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Our letters Madam, ſhew’d much more then iest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: So did our lookes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SPEECH.LINE: We did not coat them ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Now at the latest minute of the houre,
Grant vs your loues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: A time me thinkes too ſhort,
To make a world-without-end bargaine in:
No, no my Lord, your Grace is periur’d much,
Full of deare guiltineſſe, and therefore this:
If for my Loue (as there is no ſuch cause)
You will do ought, this ſhall you do for me.
Your oth I will not trust: but go with ſpeed
To ſome forlorne and naked Hermitage,
Remote from all the pleasures of the world:
There ſtay, vntill the twelue Celestiall Signes
Haue brought about their annuall reckoning.
If this austere insociable life,
Change not your offer made in heate of blood:
If frosts, and fasts, hard lodging, and thin weeds
Nip not the gaudie bloſſomes of your Loue,
But that it beare this triall, and last loue:
Then at the expiration of the yeare,
Come challenge me, challenge me by these deserts,
And by this Virgin palme, now kiſſing thine,
I will be thine: and till that instant ſhut
My wofull ſelfe vp in a mourning house,
Raining the teares of lamentation,
For the remembrance of my Fathers death.
If this thou do denie, let our hands part,
Neither intitled in the others hart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If this, or more then this, I would denie,
To flatter vp these powers of mine with rest,
The ſodaine hand of death close vp mine eie.
Hence euer then, my heart is in thy brest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: And what to me my Loue? and what to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: You must be purged too, your ſins are rack’d.
You are attaint with faults and periurie:
Therefore if you my fauor meane to get,
A tweluemonth ſhall you ſpend, and neuer rest,
But ſeeke the wearie beds of people ſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: But what to me my loue? but what to me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: A wife? a beard, faire health, and honestie,
With three-fold loue, I wish you all these three.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſhall I ſay, I thanke you gentle wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kat.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord, a tweluemonth and a day,
Ile marke no words that ſmoothfac’d woœrs ſay.
Come when the King doth to my Ladie come:
Then if I haue much loue, Ile giue you ſome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſerue thee true and faithfully till then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kath.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſweare not, least ye be forsworne agen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies Maria?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: At the tweluemonths end,
Ile change my blacke Gowne, for a faithfull friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lon.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſtay with patience: but the time is long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: The liker you, few taller are ſo yong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Studies my Ladie? Mistreſſe, looke on me,
Behold the window of my heart, mine eie:
What humble ſuite attends thy anſwer there,
Impose ſome ſeruice on me for my loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Oft haue I heard of you my Lord Berowne,
Before I ſaw you: and the worlds large tongue
Proclaimes you for a man repleate with mockes,
Full of comparisons, and wounding floutes:
Which you on all estates will execute,
That lie within the mercie of your wit.
To weed this Wormewood from your fruitfull braine,
And therewithall to win me, if you please,
Without the which I am not to be won:
You ſhall this tweluemonth terme from day to day,
Visit the ſpeechleſſe ſicke, and ſtill conuerse
With groaning wretches: and your taske ſhall be,
With all the fierce endeuour of your wit,
To enforce the pained impotent to ſmile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: To moue wilde laughter in the throate of death?
It cannot be, it is impoſſible.
Mirth cannot moue a ſoule in agonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ros.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s the way to choke a gibing ſpirit,
Whose influence is begot of that loose grace,
Which ſhallow laughing hearers giue to fooles:
A iests prosperitie, lies in the eare
Of him that heares it, neuer in the tongue
Of him that makes it: then, if ſickly eares,
Deaft with the clamors of their owne deare grones,
Will heare your idle ſcornes; continue then,
And I will haue you, and that fault withall.
But if they will not, throw away that ſpirit,
And I ſhal finde you emptie of that fault,
Right ioyfull of your reformation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: A tweluemonth? Well: befall what will befall,
Ile iest a tweluemonth in an Hospitall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſweet my Lord, and ſo I take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: No Madam, we will bring you on your way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: Our woing doth not end like an old Play:
Iacke hath not Gill: these Ladies courtesie
Might wel haue made our ſport a Comedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, it wants a tweluemonth and a day,
And then 'twil end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ber.
SPEECH.LINE: That's too long for a play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Maiesty vouchsafe me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Was not that Hector?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dum.
SPEECH.LINE: The worthie Knight of Troy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil kiſſe thy royal finger, and take leaue. I am a Votarie, I haue vow’d to Iaquenetta to holde the Plough for her ſweet loue three yeares. But mo’t estee-med greatneſſe, wil you heare the Dialogue that the two Learned men haue compiled, in praise of the Owle and the Cuckow? It ſhould haue followed in the end of our ſhew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Call them forth quickely, we will do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: Holla, Approach.
This ſide is Hiems, Winter.
This Ver, the Spring: the one maintained by the Owle,
Th’ other by the Cuckow.
Ver, begin.
When Dasies pied, and Violets blew,
And Cuckow-buds of yellow hew:
And Ladie-smockes all ſiluer white,
Do paint the Medowes with delight.
The Cuckow then on euerie tree,
Mockes married men, for thus ſings he,
Cuckow.
Cuckow, Cuckow: O word of feare,
Vnpleasing to a married eare.
When Shepheards pipe on Oaten ſtrawes,
And merrie Larkes are Ploughmens clockes:
When Turtles tread, and Rookes and Dawes,
And Maidens bleach their ſummer ſmockes:
The Cuckow then on euerie tree
Mockes married men; for thus ſings he,
Cuckow.
Cuckow, Cuckow: O word of feare,
Vnpleasing to a married eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Winter.
SPEECH.LINE: When Isicles hang by the wall,
And Dicke the Shepheard blowes his naile;
And Tom beares Logges into the hall,
And Milke comes frozen home in paile:
When blood is nipt, and waies be fowle,
Then nightly ſings the ſtaring Owle
Tu-whit to-who.
A merrie note,
While greasie Ione doth keele the pot.
When all aloud the winde doth blow,
And coffing drownes the Parsons ſaw:
And birds ſit brooding in the ſnow,
And Marrians nose lookes red and raw:
When roasted Crabs hiſſe in the bowle,
Then nightly ſings the ſtaring Owle,
Tu-whit to-who:
A merrie note,
While greasie Ione doth keele the pot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brag.
SPEECH.LINE: The Words of Mercurie,
Are harsh after the ſongs of Apollo:
You that way; we this way.
